name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 14 March 2019.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, before resuming work, I would like to mention the victims of last Monday's cowardly attack in Utrecht, the Netherlands, which left three people dead and five injured. I have already expressed our condolences to the Dutch Prime Minister, Mark Rutte, at last week's European Council meeting. Today I would like to take this opportunity to express the condolences of the whole House to the Dutch people and to the families of the victims of this terrible attack, which deeply saddens us. We must also remember the victims of the massacre in Christchurch, New Zealand, an attack in which fifty people were killed and brutally murdered while they were being gathered in prayer in two mosques. These episodes remind us once again that we must not lower our guard against racial and religious hatred: if we want to defend our values and our freedom from these barbarism, we must redouble our efforts against all forms of violence and racial discrimination. We also express our solidarity and closeness to the victims of Typhoon Idai, which has hit Zimbabwe, Malawi and, above all, Mozambique, where it has caused many terrible victims and devastation. Finally, today marks the 70th anniversary of the mass deportation from the Baltic countries, which began on 25 March 1949: in a few days, 32 000 Lithuanian citizens, 42 000 Latvians and 21 000 Estonians, mostly women and children, were deported to Siberian prison camps. Operation Priboi was a terrible crime against humanity, as established by the European Court of Human Rights. And since we are obliged, once again, to remember so many innocent victims, I invite you, as requested by some Members, a request with which I agree, to observe a minute's silence for the victims of these tragic events. (Parliament was standing and observing a minute's silence)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The Minutes of the sitting of 14 March and the texts adopted have been distributed. Are there any comments?

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: – Mr President, [inaudible] to speak on CNN to ask Jeff Bezos of Amazon to delete Soviet memorabilia on Amazon. The European Parliament should make a statement for Soviet memorabilia to disappear from Amazon; for Soviet repression to be respected, as Nazi repression. It’s time to wake up. Please, Mr President, the European people want to know the truth – the truth of the Soviet repression.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I asked if there were any comments on the Minutes. I declare the Minutes of the sitting of 14 March 2019 approved.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The final draft agenda, established by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, at its meeting of 21 March 2019, has been distributed. The following amendments have been tabled: on Monday, the GROUP of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe requested that the debate on the oral question on the rule of law and the fight against corruption in the Union, particularly in Malta and Slovakia, be concluded with a resolution of the LIBE Committee to be voted on Thursday.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, indeed we are going to have a debate later today on the oral question that you just mentioned. A vote on this was originally foreseen on Thursday, but that has been taken off the agenda, and we feel that the two should be together. We have a debate and then it should be concluded with a vote.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – Mr President. I would like to ask honourable colleagues if we could postpone this vote to next week, for one reason only. A second round of presidential elections is being held in Slovakia on Saturday and we are concerned that the motion for a resolution cannot be misused either for one side or for the other. I would like to ask you very nicely. We have two pro-European candidates in the campaign and it would be very unfortunate if any hint of a resolution were reflected in the campaign. I think nothing will happen when we vote on it next week.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I know there are elections coming up, but I don’t think that we should be quiet whenever there are elections. As you rightly said, there will also be European elections shortly, which would mean that we cannot say anything about any country anymore. The resolution is extremely balanced and factual and I fail to see how that would be unduly influencing the elections. I really do not think there is any risk. The resolution is partly critical, but it also establishes that progress is being made, in particular in the two countries that you mentioned, so I really don’t think that there is a risk. This is a non—political issue. The resolution has already been voted on in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and that was before the first round of elections in Slovakia. So I really don’t think that there is a risk, and we should not politicise these matters by taking it off the agenda. By leaving it on the agenda and voting on Thursday as foreseen, we show that the rule of law is not partisan, it doesn’t belong to any particular Member State, and it is universal. I think that’s what we should express. (Applause)

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – I am not saying that we should not discuss. Let's discuss. I don't want to withdraw an item from the agenda. I just want to postpone the vote to next week. Colleague, you don't live in Slovakia. You don't know what all the topics are getting in the presidential campaign. In good faith and in good faith, I want to ask you. As you decide – but I really want to ask you. Thanks.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: It seems to me that the GROUP of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe is not in favour of holding the debate and therefore of moving the vote. We are therefore going to vote – and this House will decide – on whether, as the GROUP of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe proposes, we should have a debate on the rule of law and corruption in Malta and Slovakia by vote on Thursday. The voting lists, on the other hand, will be available this evening.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, this is about a Tuesday vote we are going to have on the discharge. On the vote on the Commission’s discharge report there are a couple of amendments tabled, mainly by our friends from the S&D Group, about the Commission Secretary-General’s position. One of those amendments you have deemed admissible. However, you have said that another one, which talks about what the consequences should be for the position of Mr Selmayr, is inadmissible. If I read Rule 170 where you can judge whether something is admissible, I fail to see how you can judge that this is inadmissible. This is a political decision which should be left to the House. Therefore, I urge you to recall your decision in calling this amendment inadmissible and let the House vote on it tomorrow. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: With regard to the Selmayr issue, I have asked the services to carry out a check on the admissibility and inadmissibility of the amendments. The answers I had and shared led me to decide in favour of the admissibility of the amendment concerning the request for the resignation of the Secretary-General of the Commission, because this is a political request from the drafters of the amendment. Then the House, sovereign, will decide what to do. The other amendment directly connected the suicide of a poor official. (Background to the refusal by Mr Beazley) Eickhout) ... So what amendment are you referring to?

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, it’s true there was another amendment about suicide and that was ruled inadmissible. I am not referring to that, because I see the reasons why that could be called inadmissible. Here I am referring to an amendment creating paragraph 258(d), where the amendment says: ‘Given this new and serious situation, and recalling each recommendation on discharge for 2016, urges the European Commission to take the necessary action to amend definitely the unbearable position of the current Secretary-General, and this for all EU institutions’. So this is still about the position of the Secretary-General and, as you just said, that is a political decision and should be left to the House. One part you leave to the House; this part not, and I think you have already just given the answer as to why this part also should be left to the House. I urge you to please leave it to the House.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The amendment to which you refer is directly related to the amendment on suicide, which is why the services I commissioned to carry out a check told me that in their opinion this was an unacceptable amendment and therefore I too considered it unacceptable. Then, on the political vote – and I repeat, on the political vote – on the resignation of the Secretary-General, this House will give its opinion. * ** A group of Members who reach at least the low threshold and the ECR and EFDD Groups have requested that the debate on the Mobility package comprising three reports by Ismail Ertug, Merja Kyllönen and Wim van de Camp be withdrawn from the agenda.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: number of MePs reaching at least the low threshold. – Mr President, dear colleagues, at the end of this mandate, the European Parliament is about to make one of its biggest mistakes, namely to allow a package that has been rejected three times to be voted on for the fourth time without having time to see a single compromise, not a single agreement. This is going to look like a roll of the dice. A thousand and six hundred repairs are a guarantee of total mess. Vote in favour of dropping the Mobility Package and save the bread and work of millions of Europeans.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Committee on Transport considered the mobility package. name: Ismail ERTUG

We have found proper compromises through and around this Parliament, and in order to avoid the miserable situations on the motorways in Europe and to have some legal certainty, we have to vote within this term and here in Strasbourg this week. We have found a proper solution. I would like to reiterate that once again. There is no need not to vote. (Applause)

name: Antanas GUOGA

We should delay this vote, and you should know this: Lithuania and the small countries of Europe are being hurt by this. Please, Mr President, think about the small countries who are supporting the European course and who are fighting for the European course. You are hurting us with this amendment. Put that on the record.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The Chamber is sovereign. I also mentioned the problem of translation and how it would be solved. Then Parliament votes by roll call and it is the House, I repeat, that decides what to do. As far as Wednesday is concerned, the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has requested that a Commission statement be added this afternoon on the security threats arising from the rapid spread of terrorist content online.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the PPE Group would like to request a Commission statement on the security threats arising from the rapid dissemination of terrorist content online. As you, Mr President, outlined earlier, the horrific scenes in New Zealand and Utrecht, and the fact that they had an immediate global reach, only reinforces the urgency of the situation. We know only too tragically that our space online is being abused to recruit extremists and fuel hate. We cannot allow any space for terror to flourish online; our online space must be made more secure. The EU is facing a range of terrorist attacks and threats of a violent nature from both network groups and lone actors, all of whom use the internet as a means to communicate, disseminate and recruit. We believe that this is not acceptable. While I know that legislative processes are ongoing, this week must be about sending a strong political signal. It is too important and too urgent to ignore.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: – Mr President, the Christchurch attack reminded us all that we need to do more in this area; we can all agree on that. The question is how. I am the rapporteur of this file. The Commission has already made a legislative proposal on this. We are negotiating it at this moment. At this moment compromises are circling. We are having shadows’ meetings. We are going to vote on this in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) next week, and it’s going to be discussed in plenary next month. So maybe I won’t, but you will all get a chance to debate this at length next month. That is the proper parliamentary process, and we should follow it.  It is not right for the Commission to be able to give a statement to us on their proposal while we are in the midst of negotiating it in committee here. So, whilst I have sympathy with the approach from the European Peoples’ Party (PPE), I think that we should reject this request.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I put to the vote the request by the GROUP of the European People's Party to add on Wednesday afternoon a Commission statement on the security threats arising from the rapid spread of terrorist content online. (Parliament rejected the request by the GROUP of the European People's Party) (The order of business was thus established.)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Jeppe Kofod and Luděk Niedermayer, on behalf of the Special committee on financial crimes, tax evasion and tax avoidance, on financial crimes, tax evasion and tax avoidance (2018/212(INI)) (A8-0170/2019).

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, this actually is a very, very important debate. We conclude many years of work of this Parliament fighting against tax evasion, tax avoidance and financial crimes. What we have before us is the most comprehensive work done to date by this Parliament in fighting tax evasion and financial crimes and also tax avoidance. Take the example of tax evasion and avoidance: it costs about EUR 1 trillion a year. That means EUR 2000 per European citizen per year – money that has to go to hospitals, to schools, to ensure that our society has money for the weakest and the most vulnerable people. Tax is stolen, is actually stolen from the most vulnerable people. So, therefore, this fight is so important. In the European Union we have the biggest single market. We are attracting a lot of money and business, but at the same time, we are not effective in stopping financial crimes and money laundering. Dirty Russian money, a lot of money is coming into our single market without proper detection or prevention, but also without proper law enforcement and also without proper sanctions of the institutions and banks that let us down when we see big money laundering scandals. In my own country we had the scandal of Danske Bank where money flew through a branch in Estonia, up to EUR 200 billion of suspected money, a lot probably laundered from, for example, Russian oligarchs or criminals, into our single market. We have to detect it and stop it much better. Therefore, in this work we have a lot of good recommendations. First of all, having an effective minimum corporate taxation in Europe is really what we need now in our single market to stop the race to the bottom on corporate taxation. That’s the first thing and we will fight for that. Secondly, we need to end harmful cross-border tax practices by Member States. Some Member States are facilitating this but they should stop doing this, we should have fair taxes in Europe. On money laundering, we need a centralised process where we cooperate between European countries, because today it’s too easy to bring your dirty money and make it clean and use it all over Europe. This is a threat to our financial and economic stability. It’s a threat to our justice system in Europe and we need to do something about it. For example, we need a centralised Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) that could cooperate and ensure that our national law enforcement really implemented the anti-money laundering legislation we have adopted in this Parliament. We have a problem of implementation. We also see that when the biggest corporations on this earth, the tech giants, are doing good business here, creating a lot of value in their interaction with European users, they do not pay fair taxes on the value they create. We need to also call on them to pay fair taxes and we need legislation to ensure that that happens. We need a common, consolidated corporate tax base. We need transparency, so we need country-by-country reporting when it comes to corporate taxes so we can also see whether they behave in a socially responsible way. And we need our countries, our Member States, to ensure that they follow the standards they should. I have to say that it’s a big step forward that this Parliament and Commission and Council has taken to make a list of third countries’ non-cooperative jurisdictions. But, if you applied some of the same criteria that we use on third countries on European Member States will see that some of them fall short. They also facilitate aggressive tax planning and that had to stop – our own government has to stop this practice that is harming their neighbour, even in the European Union. Therefore, I think before us we have a very good and comprehensive report but I have to say that a lot has to be done in the future as well. Therefore, I also call for a more permanent structure in this Parliament to deal with taxation and financial crimes. We want to be successful, we want to continue our work. Thank you for your attention.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Thank you, Mr Kofod. Now, for four minutes, the second rapporteur, Mr Niedermayer.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, the report concludes the work of the Special Committee on Financial Crimes, Tax Evasion and Tax Avoidance (TAX3) and includes around 300 amendments that aim to close the remaining loopholes in legislation in the area of financial crime and tax evasion, as well as to propose a solution to new issues revealed by the recent scandals and findings. We discuss not only money laundering or tax fraud, but also digitalisation, distances and growing interconnectedness. It seems that existing tax systems are not addressing this issue properly, and we are facing big problems in the area of tax collection. Our report also reflects the previous revelations of the TAX2 and PANA Committees, as well as the work done on the reports, especially the report on increased transparency of corporate taxation that I had the pleasure to prepare for Parliament with Anneliese Dodds. Since the first initiative of the Parliament in this area, many things have changed. There is an improvement in transparency. We are improving the fairness of taxation and trying to simplify the tax regime and improve cooperation between the Member States in the area of the exchange of information. There has been a significant improvement on a global level. I am not only talking about the BEP Initiative that is introducing new standards in this area globally, but also about upcoming work in the area of digital taxation. As a result of that, we are witnessing an improvement in transparency in taxation all around the world, but we should also be pushing to find good ways to modernise and strengthen tax systems in order to assure the fair collection of taxes.  At the same time, we must ensure that those who pay their fair share of taxes – especially SMEs – are not burdened by excessive red tape and that tax collection itself is not too costly and inefficient. Dramatic changes are also associated with the bigger role of digital taxation, and we must find a new concept of how to deal with the new situation in the economy. It’s a pity that the Council is not able to proceed with key initiatives in this area, including the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB) and digital taxation. I hope we will play a role in the global economy in an effort to find a good solution to the problems that emerge with the changes in the economy.  I must say that the TAX3 report is also a good example of finding agreement across the political spectrum. I am proud to be a part of finding this agreement. We don’t always agree on everything, and this is not surprising. I believe in common solutions in the areas where we cannot find solutions at the level of individual Member States and their governments, but I still believe that a significant part of taxation is the sole responsibility of the Member States and we should respect that, especially if it applies to the setting up of the minimum effective tax rate. I very much support the work of the OECD in this area, but I still don’t support the proposal made by Members to create an 18% minimum effective tax rate. I believe that many areas in the area of taxation are within the competence of Member States. But I would say that, in the majority of cases, we are able to find very strong common ground. I am glad that, after the Council, in cooperation with the Commission, introduced a list of non—cooperative third jurisdictions for tax purposes, the Commission also looked at the EU Member States and evaluated some indicators that suggest that aggressive tax planning is being facilitated by those countries. This is very important. I also very much appreciate – and I guess we all appreciate – the improved transparency in the work in the Council, especially in the light of changes in the behaviour of the Code of Conduct Group. I hope there will be a growing will among the Council Members to move forward on the most important issues that will improve the functionality of the single market.  Throughout the work of the TAX3 Committee, we dealt with many money—laundering issues. I regret that the Commission had to open the infringement procedure as no Member States transposed the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive properly. Our legal framework is very strong to protect our financial system, but it will only work if it’s implemented properly. Unfortunately, we are not moving in this direction.  We also dealt with other issues, especially the issue of golden visas, where the Committee strongly believed that were only very limited, if any, benefits on the side of the Member States that provide this solution. That’s why, in our report, we call for golden visas and similar instruments to be banned and for an increase in transparency and due diligence requirements in the meantime before this will be fulfilled. Let me finish by thanking all my colleagues who worked on this report, especially Mr Kofod, our co—rapporteur, and the other shadow rapporteurs. I especially appreciate the work of the staff members of our teams and the members of Parliament’s Secretariat.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased with this opportunity, which will probably be the last for me in this Parliament to take stock of our common struggle for fairer taxation. First of all, I want to thank you and pay tribute to the work you have done, both enormous and meticulous, and to salute the rapporteurs. The TAX3 committee met thirty-four times, carried out five fact-finding missions, interviewed hundreds of experts and commissioned six studies on specific subjects, which were then meticulously analysed. The report we are debating today extends the work of the previous PANA Commission of Inquiry and concludes a 12-month term. Congratulations to this committee and congratulations to this Parliament for this very great work done. Over the past four years, I think we can say that our two institutions have become natural allies in the fight for fiscal justice. This latest report lays out a roadmap for this fight, with another Parliament, with probably another Commissioner, with another Commission in any case, to continue. I hope it will inspire us all. To open the debate, I would like to respond to the report's most emblematic recommendations in the area of combating fraud and tax evasion and money laundering. I have said a thousand times here: the international tax system is no longer adapted to the reality of the twenty-first century. Indeed, its rules do not allow us to grasp the mobile and immaterial nature of the new economic models, which is why it needs to be reformed urgently. Having said this, I regret that an agreement could not be reached on the proposed tax on digital services at the ecofin Council meeting on 12 March. However, I believe that this work has made good progress and that the support base, which was initially extremely limited, has in the end become extremely broad. I would add that they had a merit, effective already, which was to have accelerated the international discussions. It is now at this level that the work will continue and, of course, the European Union and the Commission will get involved. We know that these discussions will be centred around two main pillars that will go beyond the digital economy: the revision of the rules for the allocation of profits and taxed duties and the introduction of new minimum taxation rules. To weigh in on this discussion, and this is the will of the Union, we must bear in mind that we are not just a set of twenty-seven, and who knows, perhaps twenty-eight Member States. We represent an integrated market, rich in 500 million consumers, with a very high average purchasing power and this is our asset on the world stage. That is why the message I want to get out here is that it is imperative that we coordinate ahead of the G20 summit. It would be absurd if there were two, three, four or even five proposals coming from the European Union, that would weaken us. Speaking with one voice will enable the European Union to better defend its interests, to better assert its commitments: a simple tax system, conducive to investment, but also, and above all, fair taxation. Having regretted the failure of the digital tax, I am pleased that the Member States have reached an agreement for a European list of 15 jurisdictions considered non-cooperative. I would like to see an end to this perpetual self-denial which weakens the work of the European Union. Success, because it is one, is of course in the list, since as such it is credible. It is the most important list in the world. But the success lies mainly in the process, in the method of dialogue used, in the many reforms it has enabled. Dozens of jurisdictions around the world have cooperated with us and put in place real tax reforms, either to get off the list or to avoid entering it. Now the situation of countries that do not have a corporate tax or offer a zero rate is taken into account, both by the European Union - but again, we have influenced the international debate - and also by the OECD. I, of course, hear the criticisms about the selected countries and the absence of some Of the Member States that have been singled out in your TAX3 report. It is a matter of difference between us, on which I sometimes find it difficult to explain myself, or at least to make myself understood. I maintain that there are no tax havens in the European Union in the sense of international standards of good governance. To say otherwise actually weakens the effort we have done together to get the exchange of information across the European Union, for example. There has been progress in transparency. That's not enough to make everything perfect, I'm going to talk about tax black holes myself. Let us say that there are still a number of countries , and here we find ourselves - that have practices that are too supportive of tax optimisation or aggressive tax planning. In order to combat these aggressive intra-European tax practices, which I refute, which I refuse, which I condemn, we have other instruments than a list: European legislation, which we have considerably strengthened, the code of conduct, state aid procedures, the European Semester. There is a nuance between us, but in truth there is above all a very broad agreement. I believe that it is imperative that we strengthen these instruments and continue to improve our legislation in order to move towards more justice and more tax transparency in the European Union.  When taxes are not collected, we know that it is the most fragile, the most vulnerable, the poorest who are deprived of the public goods they need. And it is the consent to tax that is at risk. If the richest do not pay taxes, then why would we want the most modest to pay taxes? We can go even further to eliminate harmful tax practices. I am thinking first of all of the "rulings", the multinationals who abuse them to transfer their profits. In order to avoid this, we must ensure that our transparency rules are integrated into the day-to-day work of tax inspectors. Administrative cooperation must be strengthened, ensuring that Member States devote the necessary resources to it, as we are seeing with the recent scandal, the failure of cooperation has been able to create opportunities that have been duly exploited. I am also thinking of the tax advisors who play a key role in the development of aggressive tax planning arrangements. Together we have introduced rules aimed at improving transparency on these arrangements with regard to tax administrations from 1 July 2020, which will be accessible to the Union's tax administrations, this is a very significant step forward. Again, we will have to be very vigilant about implementation. Then I think about the fight against money laundering and the financing of terrorism. Under the leadership of my colleague, Vera Jourova, important progress has been made, whether it is the anti-money laundering directive or the right of access to information for Member States. Finally, I am thinking of the fight against VAT fraud. We have strengthened the power of national administrations to detect fraud early in the investigation, we have promoted the sharing and exploitation of tax and customs information, but also cooperation between Eurofisc agencies, Europol and Olaf. We will continue to make Eurofisc even more responsive, I believe that there is a path for the future that is very important. I do not want to be exhaustive here, your report is self-sufficient, but in conclusion I would like to dwell on an emblematic recommendation of the report, which is also for me a form of political message for the European elections, for the next Parliament, for the next Commission, for the Council in the future, it is the gradual transition to a qualified majority. Not only do I fully support this approach, but I support it by proposing to use the gateway clauses to achieve this. I see three reasons that make it not only necessary, but vital, to move from unanimity to qualified majority in tax matters.  Firstly, the European Union would thus have the capacity to react more quickly and effectively in an area where, as we know, the challenges are now global, where the expectations of Europeans are immense and where the unanimous vote is unquestionably a hindrance. Secondly, qualified majority voting would strengthen the democratic legitimacy of tax decisions taken in the European Union. The European Parliament, I know you are attached to it, would be a co-legislator of the interests of all Europeans because you are their voice, and they would be better represented. Finally, the scope of tax policy in Europe would be broadened. I talked about public goods: yes, we absolutely have to have an energy tax, the fight against climate change from corporate tax. I continue to advocate for the consolidated common corporate tax base, and for that we need qualified majority voting. We will also be able to pursue broader social objectives. I talked about environmental protection, I am also thinking of the regulation of financial markets. I therefore call on the European Parliament, but also the European political parties that make up it, to seize this proposal, to bring the debate to life, because this reform is also a way for your institution, not only to strengthen its powers, but to make heard a voice that Member States sometimes find difficult to listen to, that of the general European interest. And if tomorrow, in the next European Parliament, there is a majority as wide for this proposal as the one which today fights for the fight against fraud and tax evasion, then it will be a considerable step forward for democracy, for efficiency, and it will change profoundly, and the rules of the game and the game itself.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I would first like to praise the report. It contains 410 comments and individual points. It is the result of many years of work by many colleagues, in particular the two rapporteurs. First of all, thank you, and it is the continuation of the work in TAXE, TAX2 and in the Committee of Inquiry. Secondly, the issue of tax justice, fair tax competition, money laundering and tax evasion must remain on Parliament's agenda. It is not enough for us to have talked about this for a parliamentary term, and in the end it all ends up. That is why it is right – and, Mr Moscovici, you have presented many things over the last five years, and praise for it. However, your last suggestion that Parliament has this in its hands, perhaps on the question of how we can overcome unanimity: as long as the Member States can block – all sorts of states, including my Social Democrat Finance Minister, has been against the corporate tax base and against the digital tax – we will not make any progress. Therefore, appeals are not enough. We must also name the tax havens within the EU – and I would like to contradict you on this. I would like to mention just two: this is Luxembourg, where the fund's income is not taxed, that is the Netherlands, where licences are not taxed. If we are not honest about this, we cannot be seen as a benchmark worldwide.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I am proud of our work in the European Parliament. We are the engine in closing tax evasion routes. Thank you to the rapporteurs.  If the Member States implement what is now on the table, it would be tantamount to a revolution in European tax policy. EUR 825 billion is missing from tax fraud. What could we do with this mad sum? All young people could have a chance of employment. But what does it fail to do? To the Member States.  Unanimity on tax matters must go! For almost two years, finance ministers have been blocking tax transparency when it comes to showing tax transparency. Get on with the public corporate tax return! We want to know where large corporations pay their taxes and where they do not.  Finally, with europe-wide minimum tax rates! Vote in favour of this demand in the Chamber tomorrow when we vote on the report.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking both co-rapporteurs and everybody who was involved in this report because steering through the House this important file, with so many amendments, was not easy. Money laundering has been, and unfortunately remains, a big problem within countries and across the European Union, and the fight against it is still a priority. I think the report has made a good road map of what should be improved. Cooperation with Financial Intelligence Units (FIUs) and also the Golden Visas issue have already been mentioned, but still there remain some differences which in my opinion could be fixed during the plenary vote this week. First, whereas the report appropriately condemns some banks for money laundering, it is clear that the problem is wider. My relevant amendments which noted the systemic issues of money laundering were voted down in committee and I think we can commit to this issue because it’s not only due to a few bad apples in a given year, or in a particular country or particular bank, but I think we have to understand that there are some kinds of areas in the banking sector which do some kinds of ‘pre-wash’, and some ‘main washes’ follow in other places in the European Union, unfortunately. Second, the report suggests that the EU should speak with one voice in the Financial Action Task Force (FATF). However, it is not acknowledged that there are so many EU Member States which are not even members of FATF but they are still in, I would say, the lower league on the money wall with very different countries which are not members of the European Union.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, from the first tax scandal of this parliamentary term, the Lux Leaks scandal, until now, the European Parliament has been the leading light in the fight against financial crime, tax evasion and tax avoidance. Throughout the work of the TAXE 2 and PANA Committees, we have consistently highlighted the issues and our recommendations for dealing with them in an effective manner. The report of the TAX3 Committee is the last example of this. It had overwhelming support in committee. I thank the co-rapporteurs, shadows, coordinators and all other colleagues, including staff and the Secretariat. We have once again outlined our recommendations for action at EU level. The Commission has been largely responsive throughout and has come up with a number of important initiatives. However, Member States are not doing enough. The Council has consistently dragged its heels on tax issues, and it is clear that from the perspective of the EU institutions, the Council is the weakest link. Without political will, there can be no quick progress. It is essential that the European Council discusses these issues and finds a way forward. Without this, we will be stuck on Groundhog Day. Parliament will continue to react and investigate tax crimes within the Union, but without action from EU leaders, we will remain trapped in this vicious circle. The Europeans deserve better.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, tax avoidance is so important to our citizens. It undermines public services, fuels rising inequality and undermines the social contract, so why are we failing to make faster progress? One important reason is that we have our own European tax havens – such as the UK, the Netherlands, Malta, Luxembourg and Ireland – whose governments talk tough but block the European cooperation we need to make progress. I am proud that we now have consensus across this House to ban letterbox companies from our continent and to end the outrageous scam of buying citizenship via Golden Visas, but the Greens would go further. We would push for minimum tax rates across the Union, prevent tax avoiders from having access to public contracts and stop individual Member States from having a veto to block tax progress. As we come to the end of this Parliament, we can feel pleased with our progress on tax. But we need the next Parliament to transfer the pressure to Member States. The health and future of our Union depends on them joining us in the battle against inequality and injustice.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, with the vote on this report we conclude the work of an entire legislature; a job to try to establish what the ruling is so that we lose thousands and thousands and billions for tax evasion and avoidance. The European Union, ladies and gentlemen, is known all over Europe for imposing austerity on public accounts, cutting social rights, all with the mantra that there is no money, that we have to tighten our belts. In the meantime, citizens see how that same European Union with capital in Luxembourg has facilitated tax evasion of large fortunes and multinationals and has issued nothing but statements in pursuing it. For each new legislation, there is a hole through which money continues to escape in astronomical amounts. This report shows how Switzerland is in breach of international standards of transparency. How long will we have to wait until the Union imposes trade sanctions against Switzerland and really forces it to cooperate, as do all other tax havens? How long will we have to wait until the European Commission signals Member States such as Luxembourg or Malta as tax lairs? How long will we have to wait for what we decide in this House not to be recommendations but to take action against tax evasion and avoidance? Until we take decisive action against the sacrosanct freedom of movement of capital, everything will be wet paper.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, there is a difference between tax avoidance and tax evasion. Tax evasion is illegal and should be stopped. Tax avoidance, the limiting of tax exposure for companies and individuals, is perfectly legitimate. No one wants to pay more taxes than required. In British law, directors are obliged – obliged – to limit shareholders’ exposure to taxation. The purpose of business is to benefit the people who have worked and invested in companies, not to provide a pool of money for the excessive EU salaries and madcap social job creation schemes which do not work. Only business creates real long-term jobs, not state bureaucrats. Britain cuts bureaucracy to help small- and medium-sized businesses to build employment, which is why our small business sector is strong and unemployment low, unlike France – ask the gilet jaunes, Mr Moscovici, they don’t seem to agree with the way France is run. Money laundering is of course a very bad thing, but the use of terrorism, money laundering linked with terrorism, is just an excuse that is always used. It doesn’t cost money to use some of the methods that terrorists have used. This is just an excuse to interfere in people’s private affairs and interfere in business. This is why Great Britain is leaving the EU – at least I hope so if we can get rid of this prime minister, and I must apologise on her behalf, but there we are.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The title of this report should read: "Don't steal! The government does not tolerate competition." Real fraud is not tax avoidance, it is about government activity. It is governments who take one to give to the other. It is governments who print money, depriving us of the value of our savings. It is governments that allow for a partial reserve system that allows banks to borrow the same money multiple years. For each of these things, the citizen would go to sit, and governments still expect applause. It is not tax avoidance that needs to be justified, it is taxes that need to be justified. Taxes are the taking away of other people's money by some people, a claim by some to the right to another's income. It requires excuses, not avoiding it. It is even the duty of man to avoid this, so that this money does not fall into the hands of stupid politicians who are most likely to waste it. In this context, you always say: you will run out of hospitals, for schools. Let's say you may run out on trips. Tours organised by Members of the European Parliament alone cost more than €20 million. You may run out of Erasmus to get students to go for taxpayers' money from one place to another. Run out of money for this! And glory to the Lord!

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. With these 410 recommendations against tax evasion, money laundering and tax avoidance, for more tax justice and tax fairness, we are putting on the table the largest package of demands ever made. This shows that we know what is necessary and that we also have a broad majority in the European Parliament for what is necessary. We have the support in the Commission. We have a problem: we have a lack of political will in the Member States to really take up the fight. And we have the principle of unanimity, which makes blockages possible here. I therefore call on the Member States to stop the blockade. Eliminate the unanimity requirement, so that we will get the digital tax, so that we get a common tax base for corporate taxes, so that we get a country-specific tax reporting obligation, so that we get the financial transaction tax, and the principle ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, let me start with some words of gratitude, first of all for the report and to the rapporteurs Niedermayer and Kofod for the excellent report, but also to the Commissioner, Pierre Moscovici, who has used his five years tirelessly, taking every angle, every opportunity to put tax on the agenda and with success – so my personal deep appreciation for that. The issue at hand, Mr President, is the growing inequality magnified by tax avoidance which allows the 1% of the rich and the big to shift the bills of schools and healthcare and other things onto the 99%; a growing inequality which is meeting growing resistance. It is time that we took our own political responsibility in the European Union. In two ways: first of all we need a structural reform of the corporate taxation system. It has been put forward by the Commission and it has been supported by the European Parliament and now we have to bring it into the international discussion in the OECD. The European Union has a united point of view which shows that apportionment of profit is a way to block the shifting of profits on paper, of shifting real activities. Second, there is ample evidence that at least five EU Member States are tax havens in everything but name, damaging other Members in the Union, depriving them of essential tax revenues. It is time to call a spade a spade, to call Luxembourg, Ireland, the Netherlands, Cyprus and Malta EU tax havens. We are already listing tax havens outside the European Union; it is nothing more than consistent and credible that we also label the tax havens inside the European Union. Therefore, let’s take our responsibility and vote for Amendment 96 tomorrow. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Mr Tang. You’ve been seeing the riots in France, the gilets jaunes. Obviously they don’t agree with what you’re saying and quite frankly it’s not so much the rich who are getting away with lots of money, its that there’s too much money being spent by the state on crazy schemes and the working classes are not getting a fair deal and they’re not getting jobs. You need to have a free economy, a capitalist economy like the UK, in order to have jobs. It’s the only way you can create them. They have to be created by business and not by the state, and this strangulation is not going to help, is it?

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr Coburn, was the last sentence the question?

name: David COBURN
text: – I thought it was the answer.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I sort of tried to detect the question in there, but never mind. Mr Tang, go ahead.

name: Paul TANG
text: blue-card answer. – Let me give one example from the Paradise Papers: Nike, based in the Netherlands, paid 33% in tax on profits in 2007; in 2017 it was only 13%. During the crisis they saw their tax burden fall. Do you know who paid more taxes? The people that work, that just have a wage income. So yes, the yellow vests would very much support this because its the big and the rich that benefit …   (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, over the past year, we have received a great deal of new information in the TAX3 Committee on the extent of the problem of financial crime, tax fraud and tax evasion. During our order, the EUR 200 billion money laundering case of Danske Bank's Estonian unit, one of the biggest money laundering scandals, was also uncovered. Criminal activity was allowed to continue in Viro for years, and it seems that the authorities were thing to the action. Apparently, bank managers have not been interested in the origin of even dirty criminal money or the identification of a bank customer when the customer has enough money, and this is very worrying. It is certain that parliament's Permanent Tax Committee, which will start in the summer, will have a lot of work to do. This is ensured by the ever-emerging tax scandals, the latest example being the 'Troika Money Laundering Business', which revealed massive money laundering by Russian businessmen, including through Nordea Bank. Finally, I would like to thank all the colleagues and staff involved in the TAX3 work.

name: Eva JOLY
text: Mr President, in a few weeks I will be leaving my post as an MEP after ten years of fighting corruption and fiscal justice. I leave this Parliament with a mixture of satisfaction and bitterness and a wish for the future.  My satisfaction is that after ten years, thanks to whistleblowers and commissions of inquiry into tax evasion and their outstanding rapporteurs, the Greens' demands for greater transparency and tax cooperation are increasingly being shared in this Chamber. This is the victory of our ideas and I am delighted. My bitterness stems from the lack of political will to turn ideas into action to carry out much-needed reforms such as the CSA or The Country-by-Country Reporting.  My wish for the future is that citizens will seize their immense power to make the majority of those who defend the public interest rather than multinationals, so that tax justice will be the heart of the European project and that it will finally become a... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Mr President, the right of national parliaments to defend their country’s taxation systems and decide on their country’s taxation systems must be protected. Tax sovereignty should not be up for negotiation. But the obligation on national governments to combat corporate tax avoidance and provide for maximum tax transparency should also not be shirked. This report shows that Parliament is listening to the concerns of citizens regarding corporate messing on their tax obligations, but the question remains as to whether governments are listening? During the TAX3 mandate we learned that, with the help of the Irish Government, Apple has created a new structure that has allowed it to avoid paying EUR 2.5 billion to the Irish revenue annually since 2015. Apple has done this by using a 100% capital allowance for intangible assets, as well as other means. It appears that Apple is breaking Irish tax law but that it has not been challenged for doing so by the Irish Government.  We believe that this amounts to selective treatment and we ask the Commission to examine whether this is illegal state aid. If we don’t tackle the issue of massive tax avoidance by huge corporations then we are damaging … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, everyone should now be able to understand the inherent pathologies of the European Union's so-called single market: Lux Leaks, Panama Papers, Paradise Papers, Football Leaks, Bahamas Leaks, Camp EX – and how many more financial scandals have not been revealed – show the scale of the problem. There can be no single market, as long as there are different tax systems in the Member States. As long as this is the case, we will be led to legitimate tax avoidance for the benefit of large companies and in general those who have the money and the means to do so. But the surrender of fiscal power to the European Union would essentially be the abolition of national states and this for us is unacceptable. Moreover, the peoples of Europe have never been asked whether they want this. Finally, with regard to the possibility of control by the European Parliament, we agree and support the granting of such rights. The only directly elected body of the Union is one which has legitimacy for this.  On the occasion of the national anniversary of the revolution of 1821 I wish all Greeks: Happy Birthday and Long live the Nation!

name: Anne SANDER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the work carried out in the tax3 committee is a strong sign before the European elections. It demonstrates a strong will and the ambition of MEPs to fight against money laundering, tax evasion and all financial scandals. But the ball is now in the Hands of the Member States and it is important that they show a much greater political ambition in the next term of office and that Parliament's proposals can serve as the basis for future actions. Among the projects ahead of us, we must focus on harmonising the corporate tax base, combating VAT fraud and taxing digital companies. But, above all, Member States must take responsibility and it is essential that we can move to qualified majority on tax-related issues. That's the only condition for more tax justice.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, reports on measures to combat tax abuses need to be factual, focused and clear on the causes of abuse and the remedies. On such grounds, regretfully, this report is fundamentally flawed. Unfortunately, it takes on board at face value mere allegations and suspicions. Disparate elements of financial statecraft get associated with tenuous unsubstantiated links to incipient crime. Worse, a bias against smaller states in the commercial institutions is palpable. So the experience of Pilatus Bank in Malta is highlighted. That of Deutsche Bank in Germany – though of much greater concern – is ignored. Meanwhile, financial services professionals are considered like criminals in waiting. Throughout, a one size fits all approach is adopted. The thrust of discourse follows an agenda that promotes tax harmonisation. This disregards the fact that tax flexibility is the only remaining competitive tool for small peripheral economies in the single market. Obviously, the report had to take political considerations into account. Here, however, there have been pushed close to the limit of what I would regretfully call ‘tax populism’. I repeat, this report is fundamentally flawed. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ana GOMES
text: blue-card question. – I totally disagree with you Mr Sant and I want to ask you, what have you done to prevent your country, Malta, from being indeed a tax haven that puts in question the fight against organised crime, not only financial crime but including terrorism in the EU? What have you done to prevent e-gambling, crypto-currencies, the corruption that was exposed in the Panama Papers, the two members of your government that are still in government despite being totally exposed in the Panama Papers? Please tell us, what have you done to prevent that?

name: Alfred SANT
text: blue-card answer. – All I need to do is repeat what I just read. Unfortunately, the report – which Madam Gomes will have read – takes on board at face value mere allegations and suspicions. Disparate elements of financial statecraft get associated in her mind, in her world view, with tenuous unsubstantiated links to incipient crime. This is not the way for a serious parliamentarian to move forward.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Over the last five years, we have worked here in four different special and investigative committees on the area of tax crime and also on money laundering. As a result, more progress has been made in the fight against money laundering and financial crime in these five years than in the last twenty years before that in the European Union.  However, important proposals from the European Commission are now blocked in the Council of The Member States. I am unspeakably annoyed that the grand coalition in Germany is also involved in blocking a European digital tax and binding tax transparency on the tax payments of large companies in the Council of the Member States. It is time for this blockade against tax justice to finally come to an end, and that must also become an issue in this election campaign. We cannot talk about tax justice here in the European Parliament and then block these proposals in the same party families of Christian Democrats, Social Democrats and Liberals in the Council of Member States.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Thomas MANN
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I, too, have been a member of the three TAXE committees and the Committee of Inquiry into the Panama Papers, and I am pleased with what whistleblowers, and especially journalists, have done in eerily meticulous work. My question, however, is: why have the Member States themselves, the different finance ministers, moved so little? This has less to do with party book romance than with the question of why they did not say: we will ensure that we finally change this possibility of all this being decided in the Member States, and that must take place at European level.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Mann, I would like to thank Mr Mann for his work on this I would like to say that I very much regret that you will soon no longer be a member of Parliament. I have always valued you here as a reliable bank for European cooperation. I would like to say this personally. Secondly, why do the Member States not do this? There are small states that have an economic interest in them being taxed at low rates for profits generated elsewhere. This is detrimental to the internal market as a whole and is unacceptable. On the other hand, it is also the case that a certain degree of ideology is part of it. When we started working here, many people still sang the song from the tax competition ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report The tax scandals of recent years have highlighted the unbridled imagination and, in some cases, criminal energy that corporations, banks and the wealthy are committing tax evasion, tax avoidance and not shying away from open tax theft. As a result, the European states are missing out on hundreds of billions of euros a year – as has already been mentioned – which are lacking in education, health or public services of general interest.  Europeans want tax justice, and for that we urgently need a Parliament that has appropriately strong democratic tools and instruments in the fight for this tax justice. That is why we need a standing subcommittee in this House to deal with tax evasion and financial crime.  But above all, it needs the political will for minimum taxes for companies, for strong protection of whistleblowers, and for comprehensive public country-specific reporting to effectively prevent tax evasion.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Colleagues, the request I just got from Mr Sośnierz will be the last blue—card request I am able to take, for time reasons. A number of you have also requested the floor under the catch—the—eye procedure.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. "You said tax justice. There is only one just system: when I stop what I have earned and the Lord stops what the Lord has earned. Why do you think you have the right to look into someone else's wallets and see how much you have earned and tax it?

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Dear colleague! Of course, tax justice is a term that you rate differently from me. But my first concern is that companies cannot continue to cut taxes at the expense of the general public in Europe. My concern is that effective minimum tax rates are finally taking effect in Europe, which will prevent public services of general interest from being eroded further and further. For tax justice, on the whole, also means that we finally have a fair chance of development for all Europeans in European society, in the Member States.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to thank the co-owners for their work, who, after hearing Commissioners , such as Commissioner Moskovitz, the commissioner responsible, who is with us today - ministers, entrepreneurs and experts, have made a number of recommendations at national, European and international level to combat tax evasion, to also combat and simplify corporate taxation , to combat money laundering and to strengthen two areas which are particularly timely at the moment and which have not been the subject of the action of previous committees. I am talking about digital taxation and also value-added tax fraud.  There is one point I am interested in highlighting, Mr President, which is that cooperation between Member States in this area has been surprisingly ineffective. The text says that this cooperation has been poor, dysfunctional and slow. I think we have to take this matter seriously: the figures are astronomical and, as the Commissioner said, we have to fight decisively from the point of view of cooperation between the Commission and the Member States.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, this report shows europe that we do not want, to which tax havens in Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Cyprus, Malta, Ireland and buracões to launder money from the City of London to Madeira. That of governments that prostitute the European Union by selling gold visas to kleptocrats and criminals around the world. That of governments that make brutal increases in taxes on citizens to channel billions to banks, explaining that there is no money for schools, hospitals, public services, while they let large multinationals and large fortunes benefit from tax amnesty and tax blackouts, as happened in my country, with the blessing of the Troika.  That of ministers in the Eurogroup, who continue in the race for the bottom in the jungle and tax injustice, letting large technology companies continue not to pay taxes and criminal organizations, including terrorists, continuing to benefit from carousel fraud in VAT. Citizens demand a Union of law, ensuring tax fairness, fair competition in the internal market, without tax dumping, with effective combatagainst tax fraud, money laundering and terrorist financing. A Europe that applies CCCTB and taxes on financial transactions, on technology platforms, on polluting companies that strengthen the European budget and national budgets.

text: Xogħolna hawn hu li niddefendu liħ-大ittadini tagħna. Għalhekk dejjem inkun jiena l-ewwel wieħed kontra l-abbuż tal-poter. name: Peter SIMON
text: Mr President, Commissioner Moscovici, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. For five years now, I have led the Socialist Group in the special committees of inquiry, TAXE, TAX2 and TAX3, and in the Committee of Inquiry into the Panama Papers here in this House. It was a good time. We have made further regulatory progress in many areas, and we are particularly so because, with Commissioner Moscovici, we had a congenial partner on the part of the European Commission, who, together with us, has worked together to achieve greater tax justice in Europe, for a genuine fight against money laundering. However, if we are to set up our own work for the future, it is important that we tighten up once again the call for permanent structures here in plenary, which was already contained in the REPORT of the TAX3 Committee. My group has tabled an amendment to this effect. It must be clear that we are working together across committees here, because we are all taking a different view of things. Someone who works on the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs has a different view of things than, for example, Ana Gomes from the LIBE Committee. I ask everyone ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Mr President, it was said in this debate already that we are a community of law and the law of the Treaties is clear in respect of the requirement of unanimity when it comes to taxation matters. That’s deliberately put into the treaties to ensure that smaller Member States are not disadvantaged as a consequence of bigger Member States who have bigger domestic populations and a bigger capacity to get tax in. On the second point, I reject the idea that no progress has been made. We have made progress on the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) base erosion and profit shifting process (BEPS). We’ve made progress on country-by-country reporting. We’ve made progress when it comes to clear obligations of tax authorities. We’ve made progress on the Fourth EU Anti-Money Laundering Directive (AMLD 4) but the truth of the matter is, there is no majority, sufficient unanimous majority, in the Council for a financial transaction tax, for a digital tax, or for a common consolidated corporate tax base (CCCTB). That is the reality that we face. I think another tactic has to be employed – a new tactic by the Commission where they would benchmark the best practices that are available through the country-specific recommendations, that they would benchmark the best practices and measure those practices and do it in an annual report. name: Emil RADEV
text: – Mr President, the scandals of recent years, such as the Panama Papers, the Luxembourg Files, the billions of euros laundered through a number of European banks, have proven that, despite strict European Union rules, much more needs to be done to make the fight against tax evasion and avoidance and money laundering more effective.  The report of the SPECIAL COMMITTEE TAX 3, which we are discussing today, contains a number of recommendations in this regard, including some extremely bold proposals, such as the establishment of a European Financial Police.  Given the cross-border nature of tax evasion and money laundering, it is unacceptable for Member States to refuse to share information. A culture of secrecy should be replaced by a culture of data and information exchange.   I am pleased that the Financial Information Exchange Directive, which I negotiated earlier this year, has made the main ones of stronger cooperation within the European Union between financial intelligence units. This is necessary not only for the sake of European security, but also in order to track the flow of dirty money, stop them and ... (the President interrupts the speaker)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Special Committee on Financial Crime, Tax Evasion and Tax Avoidance is presenting us with an uncompromising final report: Europe has a serious problem of money laundering and tax fraud.  The EU Member States have not done enough to fill the gaps in tax rules. The European Commission itself has avoided proposing a reform that would have put an end to the governments' veto power in tax matters, so that as many as seven Member States, Luxembourg, Belgium, Cyprus, Hungary, Ireland, Malta and the Netherlands, are in fact acting as tax havens, and this situation cannot last any longer. Europol has too limited powers: at the moment it coordinates, for the most part, the work of national forces, when they are willing to cooperate. We need a European financial police force with investigative powers.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that Parliament has done a good job in this area. So has Mr Moscovici. I believe that there is a huge social alarm throughout the European Union about tax evasion and also about what is happening internally in the European Union itself. There are two things I think we need to report. First of all, I believe that cooperation between States is not sufficient. Honestly, I think we have to stop the states among themselves from doing tax damage. There are States that are taking advantage in an absolutely shameful way of tax advantages that give companies, to the detriment of other countries. This has to be stop. I believe that a single, integrated market does not allow this. And secondly, as has been said, the rule of unanimity. Unanimity ends up being a veto right of countries that do not want to put an end to this situation. And we have to stop this with the gateway clauses, but they also call for an agreement from the Council itself. That is why we must even work on the reform of the Treaties.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the question is not whether we should fight financial crime, tax evasion and tax avoidance, but how to do it most effectively without distorting the investment climate and creating too repressive an environment that stimulates the grey economy. This report, like many others so far, recommends the creation of new sunnational bodies, which I consider unnecessary since we are currently far from the highest possible level of cooperation between national authorities, so we do not know whether the new authorities represent added value or just a burden. Let's work on better cooperation first and we'll see further. The call for harmonisation of tax rates, namely VAT, is also something I cannot support. Simplifying tax systems rather than equalling them at EU level would be much more beneficial, as in addition to making fraud more difficult, it would have a positive impact on economic growth, job creation and the investment climate in Europe.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, unlike most of us, some big business leaders don’t believe they should pay their fair share in taxes. This report highlights the scale and the international dimension of the problem. It’s disappointing, therefore, to see Theresa May otherwise engaged with Tory Brexit at a time when the European Union is showing leadership in tackling financial crime. My constituents are tired of abusive business practices. They’ve left our public purse depleted and pushed our public services to breaking point. As with austerity measures, the effects of financial crime are felt most acutely by the poorest and most vulnerable in our society. But the Conservative Party have always looked out for their own, the bankers, big business, those who already have and want more. We should therefore see Brexit for what it is – a project by the Right for the Right. An opportunity for them to turn the UK into an offshore tax haven, where the offer of deregulation fires the starting pistol on a rapid race to the bottom.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, it is clear that the report contains many of the measures in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance that we have worked on in this Parliament. I think it was a legislature where progress has been made. We now need the Council to unlock many of the things we have sent it and, in particular, the establishment of a common corporate tax base, which would be the cornerstone for actually moving towards tax justice in the European Union.  I have to say that tomorrow's report will point out some very important issues, such as the elimination of gold visas; it will also point out and denounce this very negative trend of constantly lowering nominal corporate tax rates in many countries. Some do not seem to know the effects of this majority trend in Europe — Mr Pablo Casado wants to propose that in Spain the nominal corporate tax rate should fall below 20%. This is something that goes totally against the majority trend in this House, and I am glad. That is why I hope that tomorrow this report will be adopted with a large majority.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – Mr President. Tax evasion, financial fraud or tax havens have a very negative impact, other than financial, and that is the impact on our society and on the rise of extremism. name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, we in the Greens/EFA Group are fully committed to tax justice and the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, and thus we see the TAX3 report as a basically good report. This flawed reality means, for instance, Member States facilitating aggressive tax planning or schemes that straightaway make them tax havens on a race to the bottom when it comes to corporate tax rates that undermine revenues and damage the public interest, or the lack of political will amongst too many Member States to deliver on key tax legislation, such as the common consolidated tax base, the taxation of digital services or public country-by-country reporting.
