And so let us stop false pretenses: there is much to do beyond fiscal harmonisation. Tax havens, the transfer of profits to tax havens, transparency, automatic information exchange, and we must also question this sacred cow of the European Union which is the total freedom of movement of capital, because the truth, and few admit it, but tax fraud or aggressive tax planning is inseparable from the capitalist system and expresses the class dominance of multinationals over political power.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for these dynamic exchanges, these many remarks which show your interest, and more than your interest, your involvement in these subjects. I believe that we can be collectively proud of the progress we have made in strengthening tax justice in the European Union. Since 2014, we have managed to get 14 proposals adopted, including 8 against fraud and tax evasion, despite the unanimous lock. That is more than the last 20 years and I think we do not have to be ashamed of that.  But, among the struggles that remain - because there are many left, as your report is very rich and like many parliamentarians, I would like to defend several ideas that I submit to the sagacity of those who will succeed us. First, to cut the patterns of transfer between companies within the internal market through an anti-abuse clause which I believe is absolutely necessary. Secondly, the idea of minimum taxation in discussions within the OECD seems to me, of course, to be studied but also to be defended.  Of course, we must continue to advocate for greater transparency in Member States' tax schemes - whether we call them tax havens or not, but the cause of transparency applies to everyone. There should no longer be any tax black holes or countries that may be suspected of practices that are too favourable to tax optimisation.  We must, of course, promote taxation that is fair and transparent for businesses. For me, this naturally requires the consolidated common corporate tax base, on which Paul Tang and Alain Lamassoure have worked remarkably during this mandate. We must continue the reform of VAT in order to put an end to the massive fraud that affects it. For extraterritorial VAT alone, between borders, it is 50 billion euros that are affected, of which we could easily make 40 billion savings per year. Finally, we must fight against aggressive planning between Member States. It is an important cause.  All this will require determination, ambition, combativeness on your part and ours, but also a change of rule. That is why we absolutely have to focus the debate on the passage of qualified majority voting. Again, it's not just a rule change, it's what makes it so much about changing the world, changing the air and finally being able to grasp the reality of today's taxation. This will also allow us to have an attractiveness in the world, because we are weakening if we are not able to create this fiscal sovereignty together.  For me, this must become a central theme of the European election campaign. I count on each and every one of you to defend this solution. I'll do it for me. I noted that it was defended on many benches from left to right. I am a realist, I know that it will take time to get this proposal passed because we have, unfortunately, the duty to seek unanimity in order to move from unanimity to qualified majority. Today, it is far from being met among the finance ministers who spoke about it for the first time in an Ecofin council. They will discuss it again in the coming weeks under the Romanian presidency. In any case, I fervently hope so, I ask it here in this chamber, in this Chamber. I have seen reluctance or resistance. To defeat them, we need the pressure of a Parliament, a Parliament that represents a people and that is why it is absolutely fundamental that we can position ourselves under the gaze of European citizens and influence the Member States. Many of you have noted your responsibility, I share that view. In any event, the Commission and the European Parliament will have to continue to fight side by side to promote tax justice in the coming campaign and beyond this campaign. They will be offensive and encourage all parties to seize this issue, to push them to make it a central topic of their programme for the Europe of tomorrow, to ensure that it is a common fight for fiscal justice that can continue in the future, especially in the next mandate.  But, since it will surely be my last speech, at least on this subject, in this mandate because I will still be there for the next or for the beginning of the next, I mean my conviction, after almost five years with you, that this is a subject that brings people together, which is one of the unifying subjects of the idea of Europe for tomorrow. It's true that there have always been expressions of sensitivity a very large majority, very broad, who express themselves in support of your reports to advocate for this cause. This cause has become that of the Europeans. She is the one that unites us and brings us together.  Finally, I would like to thank the European Parliament again for the great work it has done to move this great cause of transparency and tax evasion forward with us. We've done a lot. Much remains to be done. This is a fight that must continue and we will continue to do so together.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, allow me first to thank all my colleagues for this very, very good and important debate and support for the report, and especially to thank Mr Niedermayer, my co-rapporteur, and all of the Members of the TAX3 committee and previous committees that worked so hard on tax issues and also financial crimes and money laundering. I also want to thank the Commission in particular, and now also Commissioner Moscovici but also Commissioner Jourová who is here. Thank you so much. We worked very closely with you on anti-money laundering, but also on tax, of course. On taxation, I want to say that we managed to get 14 new pieces of legislation through this term, but I think we have much more to do when it comes to fair taxation. Commissioner Moscovici, you are absolutely right. I think Europe has to show the way for a 21st-century corporate tax system that is fair to citizens, fair to Member States, and of course fair to businesses. I heard in the debate today from Mr Coburn that this is the punishment of big corporations, but the Commission itself revealed that small- and medium-sized enterprises have a tax burden 30% higher than multinational corporations, so if we want to ensure fairness and equal competition we need to do something about big corporations tax dodging. I always wanted to say that during our work we saw that if you are rich enough, or if you are a rich enough and big enough company, you put yourself above the law and the spirit of the law. I think that type of behaviour should not be tolerated. I think we in Parliament, as representatives of the people of Europe, should take a hard stance against the big corporations or ultra-rich people that we saw in the Panama Papers that were not only putting themselves before tax laws, but also before laws as such. So colleagues, I want to say thank you. I look forward to the vote tomorrow, but I think we have only just started our work. In the new Parliament we need to implement and hold our governments, our executive authorities, accountable for what we have done here, so thank you very much.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. Tax evasion, tax avoidance and financial crime have serious consequences for the European budget, unduly taking away resources intended to provide services to citizens. Furthermore, financial crime and money laundering, in addition to depriving states of tax revenues, distort fair competition between companies, and are sometimes exploited by terrorist networks and organised crime groups to finance their own illegal activities. I therefore believe that, in order to counter these serious threats, The Member States must further strengthen the exchange of information between national authorities, as well as fully implement the existing European anti-money laundering directives. Indeed, nowadays, technological developments facilitate the mobility of capital by allowing large sums of money to be moved from one country to another in a very short space of time. That is why I believe it is essential to strengthen cooperation between national FIUs and law enforcement authorities by setting up a European FIU to coordinate the flow of information. With a view to strengthening supervision at European level, I also believe that it is appropriate to extend the powers of the European Banking Authority (EBA) in the fight against money laundering, and also to establish a genuine financial police with investigative capacity within the Europol agency.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the situation of rule of law and fight against corruption in the EU, specifically in Malta and Slovakia, tabled by Claude Moraes, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (O-000015/2019 – B8—0017/2019) (2018/2965(RSP)).

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: deputising for the author. – Mr President, it’s a pity that the Council isn’t here, because I think the Council should be part of this debate here today, and before I go into the oral question and the resolution, I would first like to remind us again what started this, or what triggered this whole process, and that was the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia, Jan Kuciak and his fiancée Martina Kusnirova, and I think we should always recall their names and make sure that they’re not forgotten. We are discussing today the oral question and the draft resolution that we will vote on later this year. It has been drafted together with all the main political groups by the rule of law monitoring committee, and it is the result of almost a year, 10 months, of hearings, on-site visits, meetings, correspondence, video conferences with governments, with the police, public prosecutors, journalists, NGOs, experts, farmers and many, many more. I think that if we look at the text of the resolution as it is today, it focuses on Malta and Slovakia, but not exclusively. It is on the one hand highlighting concerns and criticisms and shortcomings, but I’m happy to say that it is also welcoming and noting some very positive developments, and I think the lesson that we can draw from this is that Europe works. It is clear that the intervention of the European Union helps the Member States come back on track where they risked running off the tracks when it comes to the rule of law and fundamental rights. The resolution makes a couple of recommendations which are also summarised in the questions to the Commission. We have some specific common recommendations on Malta and Slovakia. One is a recommendation to the European Commission, inviting the European Commission to start a rule-of-law dialogue with Malta. We think that that would be justified. At the same time, I also intend to put forward amendments recognising the fact that the Maltese Government has now announced that they will implement the recommendations of the Venice Commission – but nevertheless, I think a dialogue would be appropriate. We would also recommend that the brain behind the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia is caught. Not just the people who committed the murder, but also the brain behind it. And we also have a general call to end the scheme of golden visas and golden passports, not just in Malta but in all Member States. With regard to Slovakia, we note that the probable brain behind the murder has not only been caught but also charged with, amongst other things, the murder of Jan and Martina and I’m happy to say that further inquiries into corruption and connections with organised crime are being conducted. Nevertheless, some concerns remain concerning the so-called system of revolving doors. We see some of the people who stepped down actually coming back in other jobs. And we would also urge the Slovak Government to end the deadlock in the nominations to the Constitutional Court, and to refrain from adopting the new media law. And finally, there are some general recommendations to all of us. First of all, it has become clear to me in the course of the work of the rule of law monitoring group that we need to strengthen Europol because now Europol can now basically only do its job when it is invited by the Member States. People will say, yes, that’s subsidiarity. But we also see that when public authorities themselves are engaging in wrongdoing, we should have the means, as the European Union, to come in. Why? Because we are a system all together. If one of the Member States undermines the rule of law, if one of the Member States doesn’t apply our common rules and standards, then basically the whole European system is broken. So I think we have every reason to strengthen that system and strengthen Europol. I would also call on the Commission to reinstate its annual corruption report, because we don’t feel that the current formula in the European semester is strong enough. And finally, we would urge the Commission, in particular Mr Timmermans who is not here today, to finally respond to the call, the repeated calls, of the European Parliament for a comprehensive mechanism, the so-called DRF pact – the democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights pact. And I see that neither Spitzenkandidat, Mr Weber and Mr Timmermans, is really committed to a comprehensive, non-political objective mechanism, and the Member States only want a peer review mechanism. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Commission fully shares the commitment of the European Parliament and its Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), to ensure respect for our common European values. The Commission has taken action by initiating, for the first time, the procedure set out in Article 7 of the Treaty in relation to the actions of the Polish Government. The European Parliament initiated the procedure in relation to the actions of the Hungarian Government. The Commission has used its role of guardian of the Treaties by launching a number of infringement proceedings related to the rule of law. All EU Member States are monitored by the Commission in the context of the European semester. In 2019 the Country Report on Slovakia stresses, in particular, that long-standing concerns regarding the independence of the judiciary remain largely unchanged and do not appear to have been addressed. The 2019 Country Report on Malta underlines that recent reforms have not fully ensured the independence of the judiciary, as also confirmed by the Venice Commission of the Council of Europe, and I agree that we have to continue the dialogue with Malta, and we will do so. The European semester assessment also increasingly prioritises the fight against corruption. This is important for our economy and society. Since 2015, Slovakia has received recommendations on fighting corruption on a regular basis. The Commission raised concerns about the accountability of the police and the low number of criminal prosecutions, as well as the insufficient protection offered to whistle-blowers. As for Malta, the Commission is concerned about the lack of efficiency in handling high-profile corruption cases at both the level of investigation and prosecution. The Commission addresses these recommendations on a yearly basis with both countries. Let me now turn to the safety of journalists and media freedom. As regards safety of journalists, the Commission stands firm on the protection of freedom of expression and media freedom. Democracy cannot survive if journalists are no longer able to report freely, if they are intimidated, harassed, threatened or even killed for doing their job. It is crucial that the masterminds of the assassinations of Daphne Caruana Galizia and Ján Kuciak and his fiancée, Martina Kušnírová, are brought to justice. Law enforcement and police investigations into individual crimes remain an individual Member State competence, but Member States have a number of obligations when investigating such crimes. They also have positive obligations to create favourable conditions so that freedom of expression can be effectively exercised. I have to repeat again exactly what I offered both to Malta and Slovakia, that our agencies Europol and Eurojust are fully available to support the investigation into those horrible case. Now let me turn to the investor citizens schemes and investor resident schemes. As regards investor citizenship and resident schemes in the EU, the Commission adopted a comprehensive report on 23 January 2019. As a next step, the Commission proposes to set up a group of experts from the Member States to look into the specific risks that arise from investor citizenship schemes. This group will develop, by the end of this year, a common set of security checks for investor citizenship schemes. The Commission intends to present in June an initiative on further strengthening the rule of law within the Union. To prepare this, the Commission intends to adopt a communication on the state of play and the possible next steps for further strengthening the rule of law in the Union, with the objective of consulting all institutions and interested parties. The work of the European Parliament is particularly relevant to feed the reflection on the future initiative. The Commission will take due account of the resolution on an EU pact on democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. In this context, it will also consider proposals including those relating to the use of possible peer-review mechanisms on the rule of law.

text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The rule of law and democracy are a prerequisite for people to feel safe. Trust is only possible if rules are respected, corruption and political arbitrariness are prevented and freedom of expression is respected. This applies not only within the state, but also intergovernmentally. Concern about developments in individual Member States is therefore not interference in internal affairs, but rather a pan-European responsibility.  In many Member States, there is cause for concern as to whether this basic understanding is actually being respected. In the case of Poland and Hungary, article 7 procedures are already under way. In Malta and Slovakia, the murders of Daphne Galizia and Jen Kuciak, who were on the trail of the criminal dimensions of corruption in their countries, have unsettled the European public.  Our working group has worked intensively on the process of investigating these crimes and the structures in the judicial system of the countries concerned. The question of whether this is a systematic violation of the rule of law was also decisive. In both countries, there are indeed structural problems. In the case of Malta, therefore, the Venice Commission has also been tried, and its proposals are also being taken up. Unfortunately, there are also legitimate doubts as to whether the consequences are truly sustainable – both in terms of the independence of the judiciary and the freedom of the press. name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union's continuing inability to combat phenomena that threaten the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in some Member States, including Malta and Slovakia, has been repeatedly highlighted by Parliament, without the other European institutions having followed up with appropriate action. For years we have been advoca ing the need to establish a European monitoring mechanism to prevent and combat certain violations. But once again we find ourselves asking the Commission what measures it intends to take with regard to the shortcomings concerning the separation of powers, the independence of the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organised crime, the safety of journalists and the freedom of the media. One phenomenon, for example, that is not confined only to Malta concerns the programmes relating to golden visas and their impact on the acquisition of Eu ropean Union citizenship, entry and residence rights, which have become a bargaining chip in order to obtain substantial investments from foreign nationals, which are not always subject to strict rules of control and transparency. Here, precise rules are needed in this respect, in order to better preserve the borders of the European Union from criminal activities. The fight against corruption must be supported in Europe by closing legislative gaps in the prevention and fight against corruption, and that is why we are waiting in Europe for measures such as, for example, those contained in the "corrupt sweep" law passed in Italy, which provides, among other things, for the Daspo ai corrotti in the Public Administration, undercover agents and total transparency in party funding.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: – Mr President. I want to support this resolution, which is not directed against the citizens of Malta or Slovakia, but vice versa, is for their protection and is directed against certain political practices, both by the Government of Malta and slovakia. This resolution is based on the protection of democratic values and they must be respected by all governments. As far as my country is concerned, Slovakia, we were shocked that someone dared to murder a journalist and his fiancée. We were even more shocked to learn that the tentacles of the Italian mafia went straight to the Government Office and that there were people in my country who were planning the murder of three other important people, a prosecutor, a deputy attorney general and a well-known lawyer who had previously served as Minister of Justice. Tens of thousands of marches have been held several times in the country to protest against corruption and political practices. So let me thank the European Parliament, which, through its activities, has clearly sided with citizens who reject such distortions.  I would also like to point out that the Slovak Parliament has long ignored the request of the European Parliament's Petitions Committee to reconsider its position on the application of the principle of collective guilt to a group of its own citizens. I am talking about the resolution of the Slovak Parliament of 20 September 2007 and I ask the European Commission to check that this resolution is in line with the basic documents of the European Union.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – Mr President. A year ago, in the immediate aftermath of the murder of the journalist Ján Kuciak and his girlfriend, we all expressed our conviction, here on this ground, that the law enforcement authorities would be successful and that justice would prevail. Today, I am very happy to say once again in the European Parliament that justice has been given the backing that five people in particular have been accused of ordering and carrying out murder. Two weeks ago, the Prime Minister of the Slovak Republic, Peter Pellegrini, spoke here in plenary about, among other things, how his rule of law government is taking action and fighting corruption. The Government of the Slovak Republic approved and successfully launches the draft anti-corruption policy of the Slovak Republic for the years 2019 to 2023, which focuses primarily on public administration, central state authorities and which is based on western European standards and OECD ideas. However, we must tell ourselves the truth. It is not only in Malta and Slovakia that corruption must be combated. The statistics speak clearly. Every year, the European Union loses EUR 1 trillion in tax evasion and avoidance. The question is when the EU will have tax havens and when the real European legislation will come, which will prevent fraud and tax evasion and abuse in the use of EU funds. Finally , I still have five seconds – Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your visit to Slovakia and your very positive comments on the Roma issue.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I have repeatedly been to Both Malta and Slovakia in the past year and this year, and I must say that I have been somewhat appalled by the number of cases where european union rules have been violated.  The citizens of both Malta and Slovakia are hoping for the European Union to help them fight the very things that have killed the two journalists mentioned. It is, firstly, corruption and, secondly, the dysfunction of the rule of law. Let's not talk about this thing not being well known. It is well known, and we really need to be sufficiently tough and uncompromous, both as Members of the European Parliament and as representatives of the European Union, not only in investigating these cases, but in setting better rules. The European Union must prove to be not a toothless machine that tolerates some excesses, but as one that demands a thorough investigation and setting the rules for the future so that such cases do not happen again.

text: – Mr President, the European Union is a community of laws based on democracy, human rights and the rule of law. (adjourned by the President)

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Jourová, Slovakia and Malta are two Member States of the European Union, and their citizens are represented in this European Parliament and deserve all our respect. But there is not a single Member State that can get rid of the focus and priority that this European Parliament has placed on the rule of law and the fight against corruption, which means ensuring information pluralism and judicial independence in the investigation of crimes. There have been two murders of journalists, highlighting the need for Slovakia and Malta to do their homework to fully clarify, with Europol's cooperation, these killings. Ensuring the safety of journalists and combating corruption also means ending schemes of golden visas that allow illicit investment, money laundering from illicit businesses, as well as the need to ensure transparency and the assurance of whistleblowers who report serious crimes that may take place and which need to be purged in court.  It is therefore essential — and we have told prime ministers at their appearances in this Parliament — for Malta and Slovakia to clarify these killings as soon as possible.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this has been a very important debate because it covered several existentially crucial and important topics. We spoke about the rule of law and freedom of the media. We didn’t speak so much about the necessary space for civil society, which is also part of the same thing. Whenever we see a worsening of the situation in a Member State, we see that it usually refers to all three of these pillars, which we should pay attention to. I will now stay more with the rule of law principle and the mechanisms the Commission uses to uphold and monitor the rule of law in the Member States. As I said before, we use the whole toolbox and all the instruments available. We launched Article 7 for the first time. We are covering this important issue in the European Semester. We use infringements where possible and where needed, and we also use something which I didn’t mention at the beginning, the Justice Scoreboard, which is a very useful yearly benchmarking exercise and shows, among other things, how the people, the citizens and the businesses in all the countries grasp and perceive the independence and quality of the judiciary system. We are also newly adding the criteria of how the fight against corruption is done in the Member States. So these are all the instruments we have in our toolbox. Let me now say a few words about the new initiatives. As I said at the beginning, we plan the communication on the rule of law to clarify what we mean by the rule of law – that it is not purely a Member State issue, but is a European issue which has been covered by the recent case law of the European Court of Justice and which will be fully reflected in our communication on the rule of law. Another initiative is the linking of the rule of law with the new budget. I think that this should also be mentioned here. We also adopted the new initiative on the protection of whistle—blowers and, last but not least, the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, which should start working from 2020, is a very important contribution to the fight against corruption and financial crime related to EU money. This is a long list of initiatives. We need to enforce the law, to bring all these initiatives to life and to explain to the citizens of the EU why we are doing this and why it is very important. I spoke about the need to uphold the rule of law and to run all these initiatives from the side of the European Union. At the same time, as a citizen of the Czech Republic, I would like to add that maybe I feel a similar thing to some of you, namely that we should trust more the people living in our countries and our Member States, that there are democrats and that they have enhanced a way to solve the problems. They should not be put aside. We should trust them and we should trust the active citizens. That’s why I also mentioned civil society organisations and the active citizens who raise their voices and express their dissatisfaction if something is wrong in their country. I am not calling for demonstrations, I’m not calling for riots, I just say we should trust more the people living in our Member States because they are democrats and they know what to do – among other things, to go to the elections and vote for democratic powers.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Marita Ulvskog, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on discontinuing seasonal changes of time (COM(2018)0639 – C8-0408/2018 – 2018/0332(COD)) (A8-0169/2019).

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In a few days, we're going to change the clock for daylight saving time again. It will be the second time in the last six months that we are changing our clocks. We have had this change of time, which we have been carrying out twice a year, for decades. The purpose when the time change was introduced was to save energy. But that's no longer the case. With new technologies and other living habits, we earn nothing from the transition. We don't save energy.  I have been an MEP for ten years and during these years I have received countless emails and letters and calls from people on a variety of issues. But one of the issues that has come back at regular intervals is that you feel bad about the time change. Those affected, affected differently. For some it is not so much trouble, others react very strongly. It is mainly vulnerable groups such as children, the elderly, long-term sufferers and groups that already have physical, and perhaps sometimes mental, problems that suffer from the transition. Against this background, it is very reasonable for us to review the seasonal time change system. It doesn't save energy. It is likely to lead to a negative impact on many people.  Starting with the fundraisers and citizens' initiatives of people in different EU countries, we in the European Parliament have been given the views and experiences of very many citizens. In fact, there is no other subject that has touched and involved so many European citizens – ordinary European citizens who are not deeply involved in politics – as the change of time. Lots of people get in touch. They do so in letters to us in the European Parliament, they did so through a survey carried out by the Commission last year. It is about millions of Europeans. And then it is actually time that we, as elected representatives, listen to these reactions.  In the last six months, when we switched to winter time, I have been working on a proposal to abolish the change of time. It has since been prepared and voted through in seven of Parliament's various committees, which also shows, among other things, how many areas are affected by this change of time. The proposal now is that we should abolish the change of time in autumn 2021. It gives citizens a very clear message that we have listened and, at the same time, we also give clear information to the parties concerned that our internal market should have plenty of time to change and not be adversely affected. It must be done in an organised manner, this conversion, so that we continue to have a well-functioning internal market in terms of transport and a lot of other things.  The abolition means that EU Member States must decide on what permanent standard time they should choose to have accordingly. This must, of course, also be done in an organised and coordinated manner. Of course, we must not create a patchwork of different times in Europe. I therefore also propose that the Member States should cooperate with each other when choosing the time and that they should inform each other and the Commission by spring 2020. But get rid of the unnecessary time change. I hope that everyone listens and votes in favour.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would first like to express my gratitude to the rapporteur, Ms Ulvskog, to the shadow rapporteurs and to the members of all six committees of this House that have adopted opinions on the Commission’s proposal. As you are aware, the Commission decided last year to propose the discontinuation of the seasonal time change. This was done in response to calls from this Parliament, from several Member States and from many citizens that have been writing to me and to other Commissioners during our mandate. Available evidence suggested that the justification for the time change arrangement currently applicable has become irrelevant. It is equally clear that a discontinuation would help to make people’s lives easier and deal with some health issues that have been related to the current system.  The results of the Commission’s public consultation are very straightforward: 4.6 million Europeans responded, of which 84% supported the abolishment of the clock change. In this context, we very much appreciate the support given by the rapporteur and the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN) for stopping the changing of clocks in the EU twice a year.  As you know, the Commission has been deliberately very ambitious and proposed to see the last seasonal time change already this year. However, given that the Council has not yet established its own position, we recognise that it becomes impossible to meet such a deadline. I therefore take good note of your report’s position in favour of stopping seasonal time changes in 2021. Allow me to comment further on some of the amendments tabled, which we see as more challenging. First, you have proposed to introduce a new coordination network involving Member States and the Commission to discuss jointly and assess Member States’ decisions on standard time and their impact on the internal market, and if the Commission considers that the choice of a Member State would significantly affect the proper functioning of the internal market, the Member State in question would have the obligation to defend its choice and explain how it will address its negative impact. The Commission sees very well the intention behind such amendments and shares the view that an adequate coordination between Member States is necessary. However, the choice of standard time is a Member State prerogative. There is no change here. The decision on standard time has always been taken at national level.  The Commission cannot support new legal provisions in the directive that would not be in line with this division of responsibilities between the EU and Member States and would not respect the principle of subsidiarity. This being said, I would like to reassure you that I know from my discussions with Member States so far that all of them see as clearly as we do the need for a coordinated approach. I am confident that they will choose their respective standard time in a responsible and coordinated manner. No one wants to see a patchwork of time zones within EU.  Secondly, the Commission has legal concerns with the proposed empowerment to postpone the application of the new arrangements via a delegated act. Such an empowerment should in principle only relate to non—essential elements, while the entry into force is clearly an essential element of the proposal. To conclude, let me thank you once more for all your constructive work. I now look forward to the debate and to your vote. Indeed, having the European Parliament adopting its position before the parliamentary recess will sent a very clear and strong message to Council that this House is ready to take this proposal forward towards a successful outcome.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: draft opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is very important to change the approach to Directive 2000/84/EC. It may have political significance, but it is the citizens in referendums and opinion polls themselves who have expressed the position that they do not want a seasonal change of time. More addition, this change has economic aspects on which I do not wish to comment, because they are probably very complex, especially with regard to the various activities of the common market. However, as rapporteur for the ENVI opinion, I would like to stop for a moment on health issues.  Firstly, all the studies in this area, also carried out within the framework of the new discipline of chronobiology, as well as public health statistics, such as the increased number of heart attacks, suicides, road accidents that occur during this period, support the fact that this is a phenomenon for public health and the health of the citizen. The ENVI Committee therefore supported the position that the seasonal time change should be abandoned as soon as possible and the European Union directive on the matter should be repealed. At the same time, we are in favour of member states harmonising their standard time in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity. We are aware that these countries are in different latitudes and that the sunshine time in the north and south of Europe is different.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. There are certainly more important issues in the European Union at the moment than the abolition of the time change. Nevertheless, in an online petition, more than four million people in Europe have called for us to abolish the time change.  The Commission delivered very quickly. I was draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Industry, and we also delivered very quickly from our committee. The majority in the Committee on Industry has also clearly argued in favour of abolishing the time change in Europe. I find it regrettable that the abolition will not come quickly, but probably not until 2021. However, there are also good reasons for this from an industrial point of view, for example in the aviation sector, where time slots are at stake, which are often pre-negotiated for several years – and there is no such thing as rapid reaction – or even in the case of gas network operators. Now, however, it is not up to the Commission, it is no longer up to Parliament – we will most likely vote in favour – but it will be up to the Member States. The Member States must now ensure that we avoid a patchwork at European level. There are doubts as to whether they will get there. That is why I call on the Member States to react quickly and to respond to the will of the citizens, the will of the Commission and the will of the European Parliament.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, greetings to our dear Commissioner. We have often talked about this subject in this House. It is clear that this is not the most important topic in the world and not in Europe, but it is, of course, very important because of the aspects that we have also mentioned here, from the health, including the economic and many others that we have seen in recent debates. However, I think, which has also confirmed the opinion of the IMCO Committee, that we support the effort to stop the clock moving, but at the same time, of course, we are reminded that we must also assess all the consequences of this change, which will certainly occur in many sectors, including the transport sector, including in a particular sector of the economy. And therefore, a certain time frame is needed to adapt to this change. It is also true that we must do everything to ensure that there is no confusion in the European internal market and that we do everything possible to try to unify and anticipate this rainbow of change in advance.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. Mr President, I would like to thank the As draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Social Affairs, I am particularly concerned about the following points: we currently have three time zones in Europe, and scientific studies show that the annual time change has an impact on the biorhythm and health of citizens and also on animals. Families with young children and dairy farmers in particular are aware of the problems that arise from the twice-yearly time changeover. In the AGRI Committee, we decided to introduce the standard time from 2020. However, the following must be taken into account when abolishing it: the internal market must continue to function. To this end, coordination between Member States is crucial. And what absolutely must be prevented is a patchwork of time zones in the different Member States. The Member States should decide together: do we want a standard time or daylight saving time throughout the EU? So we make sure that the clock turning is brought to an end as early as possible, but with as much coordination time as necessary!

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Rapporteur of the Committee on Legal Affairs. – Mr President, Commissioner, the report on the end of the summer and winter time rotation, which we will be voting on tomorrow, is a compromise that I fully support. This report, if adopted, will be a great success for the European Parliament, which will fulfil the wishes of many Europeans. The report is the result of the work of a group of 70 MEPs across the political spectrum of all eight factions of Parliament, which I have had the honour of coordinating since the beginning of this mandate. The content of the proposal is that we end the rotation of summer and winter time in 2021. The reason for this is mainly the negative impact on human health. At the same time, it is important that this initiative does not limit the functioning of the internal market, and I am therefore glad that the proposal contains an insurance policy which gives the Commission the power to extend, where appropriate, the date of implementation of the Directive by 12 months. I am glad that we have done a substantial part of the legislative work on this proposal now before the European elections, and I call on the Council to do its part as well as the European Parliament and the Commission.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, there can be no misunderstanding that I personally am a strong supporter of daylight saving time. Especially the sportspeople and the bikers, like you, we really like this system. But to speak with Mr Koch and Annie Schreijer-Pierik, if 20% of Europeans suffer from this change of time, then we need to look at it seriously.  There's quite a bit to hagt out on the survey. Five million people responded, 497 million people did. That is also something to take into account, Commissioner.  As I have already said, I support the transport committee's report. A number of business elements, including energy savings, have expired. However, there is a risk that the internal market will suffer. I very much regret that you are already rejecting the coordination mechanism in advance. The coordination mechanism developed by the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs is indeed needed to keep the internal market and therefore the transport sector afloat. I hope you will think again.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the citizens of Europe have asked for an end to the shifting of clocks, and we in the European Parliament now have a duty to respond to this request. That shifting of clocks is artificial and should go down in history. Several studies have shown, as Marita Ulvskog says, that its benefits are minimal and the harm to health, for example, is more serious than thought. However, a European perspective is now needed on this issue. Member States must coordinate their time systems so that fragmented time zones do not arise within the EU, which is why the functioning and safeguarding of the internal market is essential. The Commission was more radical than we were and would have stopped this year. This is, of course, impossible, but I am in favour of a timetable for implementation as quickly as possible. I hope that the Member States will agree on this time system as quickly as possible.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Indeed, the majority of Europeans have spoken out strongly against the change of time. This is an outdated custom, of which there is more harm than good. It is very good that our demand that this change take place only in 2021, because the European Union is not, after all, a lonely island. We have communication agreements with countries in all time zones and these agreements are signed in advance.  The way in which the Commission has prepared this project from a technical and substantive point of view is truly scandalous. The lack of a decent impact assessment was downright embarrassing for us. All this should have been communicated to us in advance, and not to assume that we would get the whole thing done right away. Well, no, Commissioner, we will not do it, and it is for transport reasons.  I am pleased that from 2021 we will no longer be switching directions. I would just like to stress that it is the responsibility of each of our countries to define its time zone.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. " Mr President, Commissioner, "Not for long enough early morning" says a saying to stress that haste is always bad counselors. And that is exactly the meaning of the agreement reached by the Committee on Transport to end, without haste but without pause, these seasonal time changes.  Without haste, because we have agreed to give two more years to allow the States of the Union to decide whether they opt for their daylight saving time or winter time, in an orderly and transparent manner; in a hurry, because we have designed coordination and evaluation mechanisms to ensure that decisions taken do not create dangerous new distortions in the internal market and its basic services.  Without pause, because many of us agree that biannual changes must end. There is a lot of evidence to support that these changes can harm, more than we thought, the health of Europeans, particularly that of the younger and the older. And it is also clear that they do not contribute to energy savings in the terms that motivated their implementation.  It is therefore a good idea to launch an evaluation committee between States and Community authorities which analyses, from April next year, the timetable proposals of each State and identifies, prevenges and helps to avoid possible problems. After this stage of pre-evaluation, seasonal time changes will end in an orderly manner by 2021.  The agreement also provides for extensive assessments which will make it possible to verify that what we have decided does not actually produce more problems than it intended to solve. Following this roadmap, we need to show the 4,600 000 citizens who participated in this public consultation that the European institutions listen, which are nearby, that they work seriously and rigorously on citizen concerns and that they are trying to play their part: to inform the the other, to moderate between countered positions and to decide, trying to set balanced positions with transparency. If with this way of doing we generate trust and proximity, the time we spend ending the time changes in order will be gold.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Some of my colleagues here in plenary seem to be asking whether the Commission has nothing more important to deal with than the question of whether we should continue to reset our clocks twice a year. They have clearly not understood how important this issue actually is. More than 4.5 million citizens across Europe have spoken out, and a large majority want Europe to stop seasonal changes. In addition, there is scientific evidence that there are major health benefits to having a single time all year round. Every time we set the clock, the number of heart attacks, suicides and road accidents increases the next day. Now some are concerned that the adoption of this directive will lead to a patchwork of different time zones, but thanks to our green amendments, we ensure that there is a coordination mechanism that minimises that risk. This proposal is well thought out, accurate and delivers what is demanded by Europe: a harmonised approach to the abolition of time change.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, time regulation has become one of the big EU issues, especially in my own country, and I understand that very well, because this is a simple, concrete, easy-to-deal issue, which is why we have to take – and it is good that this has been taken – seriously. We have consulted people and acted very quickly on what is perceived to be an important issue for them. And even if we are not getting decisions for this year or for the next one, the fact that we have a date or a date, a year to the fact that we are taking this decision, is of enormous importance to people. The health effects on humans and animals are undeniable: the effect of light on the human mind, mental health, balance, coping. All the impacts that we can take into account in transport and industry are important so that we understand that we are giving enough time to adapt safely to the situation. I believe that we will be able to find a coordinated, smart solution to an issue that has really awakened the public's interest in Europe and European decision-making.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, unfortunately, there are many reasons why I disagree with this proposal. Firstly, there is a lack of an adequate and necessary impact assessment by the European Commission, indicating the negative effects that the change in the working regime would have on people's lives, their productivity and the environment. Furthermore, this directive would have an unreliable and unclear effect on many cross-cutting sectors such as agriculture, trade, where competition could be distorted, and energy, which could see an exponential increase in annual consumption. In fact, the adoption of summer time in the summer months results in considerable savings in terms of electricity used each year within the Union, and the adoption of this bill could be extremely damaging in this regard. Another aspect that is not acceptable is the discretion left to the Member States in deciding on the time regime that they consider most appropriate, as a harmonised framework at European level is appropriate both internally and in relations with third countries. In conclusion, I would like to stress that there is no well-founded scientific support and certainly to say that the change of time has a negative impact on people's health and safety and that citizens' consultations have been conducted in an unsuitable manner and without any real debate in the various States.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the semi-annual change from winter time to daylight saving time is clearly no longer a reason to be. The energy savings initially invoked are no longer quantifiable and the negative effects of regular change are no longer to be proven. It should also be noted that it is mainly the switch from daylight saving time to daylight saving time that brings the most serious inconvenience. It also appears that if this summer choice were endorsed by some countries, these inconveniences would persist with serious consequences on human, animal and plant physiology.  But the heart of this issue is, as always, the concern for the stability of the large European economic market, alpha and omega of market values.  It is clear that the end of schedule changes is a necessity that must be accompanied by real, stable and sustainable coordination. But, again, by legitimately leaving the choice to each Member State to determine its daily schedules, the European Union opens the door to difficulties as only Europe knows how to create them when it builds and deconstructs in areas where it would have been well advised not to venture.  By trying to interfere in all the everyday acts of Europeans' daily lives, always in the name of their well-being, the Europe of Brussels has built brakes. When the facts prove that there was no reason to put in place certain constraints, cancelling them becomes a real headache. Let this serve as a lesson. Let us cease the unbridled production of texts, which are anything but liberating. So let's change Europe.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Reducing bureaucracy means that we should separate ourselves from what is of no use and that is not good for us. The time is ripe, let us put an end to the nonsense of the twice-yearly time change! Let us put an end to the health disadvantages for about twenty per cent of the European population, the economic disadvantages for a large number of companies, the negative effects on road safety and the disruption of the biorhythm of animals! Colleagues have now also realised that the time change must be lifted, which was previously opposed. Thank you chön! I've been campaigning for this for a decade. The abolition of the EU directive on summer time does not mean that summer time will be abolished. In the spirit of subsidiarity, Member States should decide whether they want to stay permanently with daylight saving time or standard time. In order to avoid the resulting disadvantages for the internal market, I support the planned coordination mechanism. Three time zones in the EU should be enough to ensure that the peripheral countries are compensated for disadvantages.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, this is not the first time the topic of time change has been discussed in this Chamber.  84% of European citizens responded in the largest poll ever conducted that they wanted the time change abolished. Science and experience also show that this practice is an economic obsolete that carries health risks and affects the productivity of workers. It also has an impact in the agriculture sector. This Directive is about to become a fact.  I find the proposal for a new coordination mechanism, as well as the recommendation for joint decision-making for Member States on a regional basis, to be correct so that there is no fragmentation of the now functioning single market. That's why I support him.  I call on the Council to follow this balanced approach and to adopt the directive thus proposed as soon as possible in order to respond to the interest of the majority of Europeans.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Mr President, my delegation also agreed to put an end to the half-yearly switch between winter and summer time. It simplifies the daily life of citizens. This conversion does not, or no longer, generate energy gains, as was initially intended, but it does have a whole range of negative effects. However, we are in danger of becoming contradictory in calling into question the fact that the abolition of the switchover calls into question the existing harmonisation. We certainly want to avoid absurd time jumps with our closest neighbours and our first trading partners, because then you do not simplify the lives of the citizen, you just complicate it, and you complicate the functioning of the internal market. This Parliament's call for a coordination mechanism is a good start in this regard. The current harmonised economic area must not be reduced by the abolition of the existing directive. A choice will ultimately have to be made: a permanent daylight saving time or winter time. This, Commissioner, must indeed be debated on the basis of objective data and mutual consultation and coordination will be required.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. When the time change was introduced, they wanted to save energy. In fact, you save energy in the evening, but in the morning you have to use more for heating and light. They also wanted to prevent accidents at the same time. There are now fewer accidents in the evening, but more in the morning, and school children are also involved.  Speaking of children, it has been noted that after the time change, the performance, the ability of the children to concentrate in school decrease. That is not what we really want. Chronobiologists have been awarded the Nobel Prize for finding that it can be a major health problem for people, especially for the elderly and the sick, when this time change is there, including for children. If all this has now been found out, why are we in the EU not prepared to follow suit? Russia and China have realised that there is no point and have abolished the time change. I think we should be as smart as that.  As far as the internal market is concerned, when the time change was introduced, a time was agreed. Switzerland even took part, even though the population did not want to do so. But they said that we need the internal market, we want trade – I know That Switzerland is not part of the EU – and they have agreed. That will certainly be the way to do it if we decide to do so now. That is why, please, vote in favour!

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, Commissioner in the five years I have been a Member in this place, much has changed. Nevertheless, there is one thing that hasn’t – the old adage that the EU knows best. I have to agree with the House of Commons submission of its reasoned opinion in relation to this subject, which noted the lack of sufficient evidence to justify the discontinuation of seasonal time changes. This plan is yet another example of harmonisation for harmonisation’s sake. So much for the idea of subsidiarity. Again we see your philosophy of ever-closer Union selfishly being put ahead of the rights of national governments. Mr President, it should be for an individual Member State to enact seasonal clock changes, as their economy or indeed geography deem it necessary, not the EU institutions. Should Her Majesty’s Government surprise us by actually respecting and enacting the vote to leave the EU, then I trust they will see sense and ignore this proposal.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, through today's debate, we show that we hear our citizens. I would like to join my colleagues who have said that 84% of our citizens have made it clear that they do not want us to change the arrows on the clock anymore. That is why, as rapporteur for the ERA Group in the Committee on the Internal Market, I have actively worked to put an end to this practice.  A number of studies confirm that in the days after the change of time, complaints of insomnia and loss of concentration increase, road and work accidents also increase.  If years ago the main argument for the introduction of seasonal time change was precisely the saving of electricity, then today this argument is no longer valid. There is no economic argument for health that we can make.  We have listened to the concerns of Europeans and that is why we have been working to resolve them in recent months. In our report, we make it clear that by 2021 we must stop changing time.  But now it is the Council's turn to reach an agreement and make a clear civic position a reality.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, I listened to a number of speakers today saying that this is not the most important issue that Europe has facing it at this present moment in time. How right they are! Because when you see the many problems that behold us in Europe, certainly I do not believe this is at the top of the tree, and simply doing this for the sake of it is not, in my opinion, good government and is not good decision-making. The Commission has already admitted that there is insufficient evidence to support any change to the status quo, and I think it is right in that. I come from Northern Ireland and we have enough problems, not only with the backstop and Brexit and the border, but it seems to me to be totally crazy that where I live, four miles up the road Keady and Castleblayney would be in different time zones; Newry and Dundalk would be in different time zones; Belcoo and Red Lion would be in different time zones – it just would not make sense. So we have enough problems and we don’t want to go down that road. What we have at the moment works, so I would say don’t change it now, and I call on Members to do the right thing and reject this proposal.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Why easy, if it's complicated! That is how I would like to describe the behaviour of the Council and some of the concerns here in this House. Why easy, if it's complicated! The vast majority of people have not only said in an online consultation of the European Commission – and why do we then do a consultation when we don't care what people say, otherwise the Commission takes it seriously – but also in representative surveys, it does not want it. And as a doctor, I tell you that there are health problems. The size of these needs to be investigated further. But if they are even subjective, why should we ignore them, especially since– as has been said many times, there is no advantage to this time change? And that is why we must abolish them. In my view, the things that are now being put forward are really not convincing arguments against the proposal of the Committee on Transport. The fact that we in Europe can theoretically have different time zones and a patchwork is also possible under current law. Every day, each state can decide to go to a different time zone. This does not prevent the current regulation. We are even doing better by introducing this coordination mechanism. So please: a large majority tomorrow for the proposal of the Committee on Transport, and then the Council should finally get to work.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for It would seem that the elimination of the seasonal change of time is a topic that should not raise any doubts. There should be full agreement in this House, because if we do not agree on such an easy issue, on what? We should not share, and yet there are doubts. I am pleased that I am one of those people in Europe who, in a consultation of 4.5 million citizens, voted in favour of abolishing the seasonal change of time, and I fully support their demands. Scientific, health, economic and agricultural research support this, so there is nothing but to support these demands and move away from old habits. And as this discussion shows, it is most difficult to part with old habits, even if they do not have scientific or economic powers. I regret that the change will not be announced until 2021, but I understand that member states must have time to prepare and that the Commission will no longer absolutely seek further shifts. Two thousand twenty-first will be the year when the seasonal time change leaves the lamus.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, all during my life I never saw much sense in this biannual clock change and I was delighted when came here to the European Parliament to be part of a working group that set out to end it, and of course as we progressed over the last five or six years, we got all the evidence from research which show that from a health point of view, animal welfare, energy, that the biannual clock change has outlived its usefulness. So I was very pleased when Commission President Juncker suggested that it would end this year, he wanted 2019 based on the consultation which the Commission had undertaken, which showed that 84% wanted it ended, and that was the biggest response ever, 4.6 million people responded. That must be a fair indication of the way people feel about it across the European Union. I agree completely with colleagues, so it will work effectively and to avoid the situation that Jim Nicholson mentioned, there should be a coordination mechanism so the Member States can sit down and look at it and agree on what way they will go forward. End biannual clock change and then have either summer or wintertime forever more — makes sense.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Mr President, I can say that, after a survey, so many people in Europe have never said that they want something different, and we must listen to that. Only in my own Netherlands nothing has been done about it, in Germany it has. Of course, it is no longer about saving energy, we all know that. That was then brought forward without investigation.  It's about the biorhythm of humans. We have mothers with small children, we have elderly people, we have heart failure: there are so many examples. And when it comes to biorhythm, the Nobel Laureate has put that forward. And, of course, it is about good coordination between the countries. But if we cannot do this here in Europe for the ordinary people of Europe: what are we worth? We have to work on this and I have confidence in the Finnish Presidency.  Let's really put an end to this historic mistake. Every year 500 million people suffer from it and twice a year. Let's stop that. Finally, I would also like to say that this has now been brought forward with research, that we must stop. The first has been brought forward without investigation. Seven committees have said that we need to get on with it, and in particular the TRAN Committee. I also say it to my Dutch colleagues who are here: the TRAN Committee is about transport, but it is not only about transport but also about people. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

Perhaps the Netherlands and Germany will opt for different standard times in the future. How are you going to explain to residents of your border region or other European border regions that they may need two watches in their daily lives? How do you prevent the single market from becoming fragmented? And how do you prevent the daily lives of those people, those entrepreneurs, those workers in those border regions from becoming further disrupted?

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: "blue card" answer. – We people from the Netherlands can work very quickly with Germany to ensure one time. We already have three time zones in Europe and we will certainly get out of that with Germany and Belgium. But what you don't do: you don't listen to the people of the Netherlands. You only listen to the industry and that is something I certainly do not do. I have done this report in the Chamber for more than 12 years and now have been in the European Parliament for four years. I hope you'll be working with me in another place, and that this will be over.

We believe that this change must maintain the harmonisation of time zones. It's better to do it sooner rather than later, but 2021 is better late than never.  I think that the Union must start by recognizing citizens' concerns. One of these concerns was precisely this question of changing time, because it showed how much trouble, including health, also such existential, family causes it. So we can say that it's time for us to finish this two-time change, however little bit it drags on.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the No one will deny that a minority has temporary health problems. But I am convinced that the time change has proved its worth overall. Man needs sun, he needs sunlight. And when a doctor here says that the ailments are so great, he has completely neglected this aspect.  The online survey was not representative at all: less than one percent. Four million responses came from Germany. There, too, it was less than five percent. When I look around here, not even two per cent of Members are present at this debate. What kind of mood-making is that underpins this? I do not think that is justified. The proposal is unfinished, there is no impact assessment. The rapid-fire is damaging the internal market and belongs in the bin.  That is why I say: I shall vote against. And I'm looking forward to March 31, 2019, when daylight saving time comes.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, dear colleagues and colleagues. I welcome the change and I would like us to stop moving the clock as soon as possible. The reasons for this are not just economic. First and forth, there must be a man and the question of what artificially changing time means for his physical and mental health. Research warns of a higher risk in people with heart disease and a higher chance of heart attack. Problems arise in adapting to human biological rhythm. People are deprived of sleep, their ability to concentrate decreases, there are more accidents at work. Tired or sleepless drivers cause traffic accidents during the first period after changing the clock. Although it is only an hour's difference, this can have negative consequences for people's overall well-being. Obviously there are reasons to stop moving the clock, and that is what the citizens want. However, the transition to the new regime must not cause further difficulties. The proposal aims to make people's lives easier. No one wants ten neighbouring countries to have 10 different time arrangements under the new 10 different arrangements. So back to nature and more harmonisation at European Union level. (The Speaker agrees to answer the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – I have only one very short question: what is the reason for the esteemed colleague's statement that brain strokes are increasing? I haven't read that. The American studies prove the opposite.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: The answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – So, I am relying on the research collected by my experts and I believe that they have found the right facts and put forward the right arguments.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, the European Commission wants the Member States to go to a permanent summer or winter time, but there are no arguments at all. There has been a hearing in the Committee on Transport and experts agree: all this talk about health benefits for stopping the current system, but there are no such things. And also the arguments about road safety that will improve: there are no such ones. We are purely concerned with emotion here, while there are no facts on the table that show that the new system will work. So the Commission's proposal is a waste of time. Instead of bringing harmony to the internal market, chaos and confusion are increasing. We're coming up with a new patchwork quilt that we don't get along with. So I am in favour of rejecting the Commission's proposal. Let Juncker lie awake for once. Parliament must show its teeth. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: "blue card" question. – It seems to be becoming a bit of a Dutch discussion. In my country, the Netherlands, many members of the European Parliament have not studied this sufficiently. I've been working on this for five years with a lot of others. We have reports from cardiologists, of road safety, etc. and so on, all of which are with our rapporteur on the desk. You can look at that. Now to say at the very last that nothing is going on, I think it is premature and not really do justice to the people who have worked with them carefully. I therefore ask you to look at this.

name: Peter van DALEN

There is simply no clear analysis of arguments on the table to move to a Commission system now. And what are we going to do? Then the emotion will reign, because "there are so many citizens who want it". 1% of the European population wants this and no arguments!
