name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, the debate and decision on seasonal change in time cannot be dissociated from the geographical, social, cultural and other particularities of each country. The European Commission is now proposing, in the name of a well-functioning and harmonisation of the single market, to propose the imposition of an end to seasonal time change. We recall that there is no closed position of the scientific community, nor on the way in which seasonal time changes should be made, nor on the benefits or damage of the existence of such changes and their implications for the health and well-being of the population. We also recall something that the European Commission seems to have forgotten: the establishment of legal time is the responsibility of the Member States. For all this, we believe that the existence or not of seasonal changes in time must take into account the will of their population, the opinion of the scientific community and the interest of each country, so we reject any impositions of the European Union in this matter.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, time change has consequences on people's day-to-day lives. It has economic, energy, security, conciliation implications that will affect the quality of life of citizens. Therefore, it cannot be taken lightly. The Commission's proposal lacks a thorough assessment, as has already been said, of both Directive 2000/84/EC and the proposal submitted. Decisions cannot be made in a hasty way; decisions that may end up creating barriers and time borders where they do not exist. And, before we move forward with this debate, with a debate like this, it is necessary—and necessary as imperative—to look deeply at the implications of this decision.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I have listened very carefully to this very passionate debate. Before I comment further, please allow me to clarify one very important point. It is a national prerogative to decide on the time zone – today, already, it exists. As it was pointed out today, we have three times already in the EU and this does not represent any disturbance to the internal market. I would very much appreciate it if you take this into consideration when you are commenting on this topic. While I am still noticing some resistance in your comments, I see that after a long and thorough examination, you are ready to adopt your final position in line with the original proposal that was made last year. This is a very important message to European citizens because the response to the questionnaire about the time change was almost ten times bigger than the response to any other questionnaire and any other any other consultation we ever had at EU level. So people do care. We are obliged to respond. This issue can be seen as more complicated than one would expect at first sight. This is mainly due to the division of competences between Member States and the Union, and that is today. This is not something that the Commission came up with for the purpose of this file. It is really important to recognise this division and respect it while making decisions. As I already said, the Commission will ensure, within its powers, a close monitoring of the implementation of this Directive and we will work together to avoid any transitional disruptions for European citizens and economic operators. I am personally very confident that each of the Member States is equally aware of this and they will make well-considered and coordinated choices in the months to come. But it is their choice. All the Commission has in its power is to make sure that we all make decisions at the same time. This is something we will exercise. I even encourage Member States, in order to be sure which time to choose, to do the national consultations and I believe that the time that you envisioned will be sufficient time to carry them out in a democratic, open and transparent way. At the end, let me thank you, one more time, all of you – rapporteur and Members – that you dedicated your time to this file, and by adopting your position, this House will be ready to start the negotiations with the Council after the recess. I am sure this will lead to a swift outcome, most likely already under the Finnish Presidency. Good luck tomorrow and thank you very much for your attention.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you very much to everyone who has used the opportunity to think freely and loudly on this issue. It is an extremely exciting debate, one of the most interesting people I have listened to and participated in for at least the last few years in the European Parliament. That says a lot about commitment, because it is a comprehensible question.  It is also a question of the Committee on Transport, which is such a practical committee, of course, never coming up with an adventurous proposal which in any way disrupted the internal market. I do not know, I am an old Minister of Culture from the beginning, if we had given the assignment to the Committee on Culture, it might have been a bit adventurous, but the Transport Committee is a committee that stands with both feet on the ground. This is about removing the time change that does not produce the energy-saving effect that we thought quite a long time ago. Instead, we shall now go back to an order whereby, as usual, the countries must coordinate. And then we have a time zone, we have an affinity temporally, which means that we continue to operate without interference. This is not a revolution, nor is it federalism, it is a very practical measure that will perhaps save money in addition, but which will be good for human health – and that is what makes us involved in this issue. So I would like to thank you all for an incredibly exciting debate. It has been very valuable listening to it. I feel like this could be something really, really good. We might come up with good ideas in completely different areas if we can be as creative as we have been tonight. So thank you very much to all of you.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the next part-session. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I support the abolition of the time change. The outcome of the public consultation was more than clear: 84% of the 4.6 million people who took part in the consultation were in favour of abolishing the six-monthly time change that has taken place since the 1970s. After today's vote, I hope that the clock turning will be a thing of the past as soon as possible. The most important thing now is to ensure that the internal market can continue to function properly. And I call on the Member States to ensure that there are no two-hour time differences between neighbouring countries.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "I am very pleased that we are finalising work on moving away from the relic of the past, which is the change of time. In two years' time, the European Union will be able to benefit from the stability of staying in one time cycle. There is no doubt that everyone will benefit from this, especially children, the elderly and the sick and farmers. This also means a number m.in benefits for European transport or information systems. I therefore had no doubt that I voted in favour of this directive, and I am pleased that a majority of Members were of the same opinion. However, I would now like to call on the Member States, firstly, to agree their common position in the Council without undue delay and then to coordinate the process of change efficiently and sensibly while preserving the harmonisation of time zones.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. "Studies have shown that moving clocks interferes with people's circadian rhythm and negatively affects their well-being. The transfer also has negative effects on animals. The abandonment of the movement of clocks is an issue that is directly visible in the lives of citizens – unlike many of the major issues that are being discussed in this House. It is therefore understandable that this issue has provoked a great deal of heated debate. A clear majority of the 4.6 million respondents, as many as 84 per cent, organised by the Commission in the summer of 2018 were in favour of giving up the clocks. The message from the public is very clear. I welcome the fact that unnecessary clock shifting is to be abandoned by 2021, so that member states can decide for themselves whether they will permanently monitor winter or daylight saving time.

name: Kārlis ŠADURSKIS
text: Writing. – A study carried out by the European Commission showed a clear position for citizens: 84% of Europeans believe that it is necessary to abandon the change in daylight saving time by choosing one. I can't disagree. I believe that the time has come to put an end to the regular clocks. The reasons why Europe initiated the regular time-change are no longer critiqued in the 21st century. While I would like to stop changing the clocks already this year, as originally proposed by the European Commission, it is understandable that, for example, the transport sector needs time to prepare for these changes, so I support the abandonment of time changes from 2021 on. It is important for Latvia that the end of time change takes place in a harmonised way and that we stay in the same time zone as our neighbours - Estonia, Finland and Lithuania. However, if anyone is concerned that we will stay at the same time as Moscow, I say immediately that this is not possible.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. – The attempt to abolish the rotation of time was one of the points of the KDU-ČSL programme for the 2014 European Elections, and I am proud that we have succeeded in keeping this political promise. I have supported the abolition of the rotation of time since the beginning of this debate. In addition to the general concern about the changes in time that I see among citizens in my surroundings, I based my decision primarily on scientific evidence, which has been discussed many times in the European Parliament, for the first time back in March 2015. The discussion has confirmed to me that changing time brings more difficulties than advantages. At the beginning of the last century, when the rotation of summer and winter time was introduced in various European countries, economic savings were the main motive. However, according to scientific reports, these assumptions have not been confirmed and in fact the savings are marginal. Similarly, there were predictions that changing time would reduce the number of traffic accidents caused by lack of daylight. However, studies show that the number of accidents during the spring time change has increased, in the context of shortened sleep of drivers. In addition, time rotation has been shown to cause health complications in up to 20% of the population and also has a negative impact on animal biorhythm, causing a decrease in production mainly during milking. I support the directive because it will put an end to these negative effects.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Numerous studies clearly show that the number of negative consequences exceeds that of benefits in order to justify waiving the seasonal change of time. This generates additional administrative costs and burdens for certain economic sectors, in particular transport. For example, if we stopped changing the time twice a year, we would help improve the long-term planning of freight and passenger flights. It is true that at the moment there is a divergence between Western states, which prefer to keep daylight saving time, while northern European states prefer winter time, but I think it is essential that Member States find a compromise solution that benefits everyone. The European Executive understood that there must be harmonisation at European level in this respect, and I believe that abolishing this practice will be positive for all Member States.

name: Martina WERNER
text: Deputy rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner Arias Caete, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Arias Caete, for the work he has done on this report. Today I have the honour of representing my colleague Jerzy Buzek, our rapporteur on electricity market design. Parliament's actual rapporteur, Mr Karié, has successfully concluded the negotiations with the Council and the Commission, but is now Prime Minister in Latvia, and therefore, logically, he cannot be here today. However, I would nevertheless like to take this opportunity to express my sincere thanks for his commitment, for his conduct in the negotiations and for the very good cooperation. The European Commission published its proposals on the clean energy package in November 2016. The two dossiers on the new electricity market design are the most comprehensive, if not the most far-reaching, of the entire package. What exactly is it all about? The regulation introduces new rules for the European electricity market. The electricity market has changed enormously in recent years. The roles of individual market participants, from producers to consumers, have also changed enormously. It was therefore necessary to reshape the European electricity market and make it fit for the energy transition. In the electricity market of the future, electricity must increasingly be produced on a decentralised basis, investments must be made in sustainable energy sources, and the electricity markets, which are still nationally oriented, must cooperate much more closely regionally. Consumers have a central role to play in the future electricity market. That is what the directive will focus on. From now on, electricity customers will be able to actively participate. However, the directive also aims to strengthen consumer protection. To give a very concrete example, electricity customers will in future receive invoices, which they will then understand immediately. You probably all know this: Until you get the relevant information on the electricity bill, you have to scroll a few pages and then probably look in the footnotes. From now on, the most important information will appear bundled on the first page. In addition, certified websites will be available in all Member States, so that every single European can also compare the different electricity tariffs and then choose the right one for themselves. The European Parliament has attached particular importance to ensuring that vulnerable electricity customers are not neglected. Energy poverty is also a reality in the EU today, and it is precisely for this reason that the Member States are obliged to monitor very closely whether their national measures are sufficient to support people affected by energy poverty. I would particularly like to thank my colleagues from the European Commission, who, with their expertise, have also made a decisive contribution to the successful conclusion of this dossier. Many thanks also to you, Commissioner Arias Caete, for the always very constructive exchange, even in really difficult negotiations.  The Austrian Presidency has also made an enormous contribution to ensuring that we can finally vote on this report tomorrow. We only needed six trilogues in total. Well – the penultimate time we negotiated for 17 hours and then 16 hours in the last trialogue. Nevertheless, this is, of course, an enormous achievement, that this extensive dossier of really controversial issues within the Austrian Presidency has then led to success.  I would like to take this opportunity, and finally also to my colleagues, for their trusting and very constructive cooperation, including our staff from the ITRE Secretariat and all the other services in Parliament, the political advisers, the individual groups, and, of course, I would also like to thank the assistants in particular for their efforts. Together, we have achieved a great deal for the European energy transition and for the citizens of the EU.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President! I would also like to start by thanking everyone who has been involved in the negotiations here: the Commission, the Council of Ministers and, above all, all the good colleagues here from the European Parliament. We've spent a lot of hours together, negotiated whole nights away. But I think we have achieved a series of achievements that we can be proud of. We should also have done so, because my fear is that we are - and we risk being - losing the climate fight if we are not ambitious enough! We must be here in the European Parliament, and we must be among the governments across Europe. The paradox is that while politicians are hesitant, citizens are taking to the streets and demanding action. We see how teenagers across Europe are demonstrating for a better climate and demanding solutions to the climate change that will send people fleeing droughts and floods in the coming years. They are demanding solutions to the air pollution caused by the deaths of 400 000 Europeans every year.  Too many governments are stuck in narrow national interests blocking the important green transition, and the negotiations on the large energy package are unfortunately a good example of this, because although wind and solar are now cheaper than coal, the green transition to renewable energy is still going too slowly. Although a stronger joint agency, ACER, can help ensure that wind energy from the North Sea can give Europe green power in its sockets, many governments still prefer to keep old coal power stations alive. In our debates it was clear when we in the European Parliament tried to reinforce ACER, then there were national governments that tried to water down, and when we fought for a more independent ACER, there were some who resisted. It was a struggle to give ACER more powers and resources, and it still is, but fortunately we were able to set up ACER to charge fees, which is absolutely essential for ACER to carry out its important tasks.  The types of matches are of course a big problem, because the lack of common solutions is done at the expense of the climate. We also saw this in the negotiations on the electricity market regulation, where there were Member States fighting against open and free borders on energy. But only by integrating renewable energy across borders can we win the climate fight. Fortunately, we landed a good result - sometimes not so much because of the Council as it is despite the Council. Let me be very clear: the fight against climate change is the most important fight! That is precisely why it is so unfortunate that there are many heads of government who suffer from what I would call a green amnesia. They say one thing in Paris when they sign fine declarations, but then when they sit at the negotiating table in Brussels, everything can suddenly be forgotten! Unfortunately, we saw this last week when our heads of government met at the summit to shake hands on a carbon-neutral Europe by 2050. Unfortunately, it was only by the talk! But Europe must take the lead in the green transition and in the climate fight, and we must invest far more in research and new technologies than we do today. The money can be appropriately found by coming up with climate taxes on plastics and on fuel for aircraft and on coal for me, and it is time we put pressure on those governments that do not live up to any agreements they may make. I would like to thank once again all those who have been involved in all the negotiations we have been through: the Commission, the Council of Ministers and, above all, colleagues here in the European Parliament. I think we should remember that in two months' time we will be asking our citizens to go out and vote. As politicians, we cannot and must not ignore the citizens' demands to take the climate fight seriously. We must be inspired by the popular movements and take responsibility. We owe it to our children and grandchildren!

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when we took the first steps on this crucial package of proposals for energy union, many months ago now, we knew that the path would not be easy. There were many interests at stake and resistance on the road to integration between energy markets. Well, although the path has in some ways been even more tortuous than expected, it is thanks to this frank and close confrontation, first in Parliament then in the trialogues, that the points of fall in negotiations and the best legislative solutions have been consolidated. In the area of risk management in the electricity sector, the result I proudly claim rewards the work of this Parliament on all the substantive aspects of the proposal. Let us remember the subject: today, when there is a sudden interruption in the supply of electricity – and this can happen for a dramatic event, a climatic event, a terrorist event, a particular overload, a rupture – the Member States are left to their own devices and to the good heart – let me pass this expression – of neighbouring countries, where interconnections allow this. The dynamic, as demonstrated by the winter 2017 crisis in south-east Europe, affects European citizens because it affects the usability of services, energy prices, the financial balance of households and industrial production. The question was, and is, how to promote - under conditions of energy crisis - the circulation of energy under certain conditions to where it is most needed in the Union, regardless of national political boundaries. As a Parliament, therefore, we had a task for everyone, namely to ensure that the criteria for mutual cooperation in the event of an energy crisis were properly stringent, both in terms of methodologies for assessing scenarios between countries and countries, and therefore on the principle of interoperability, as well as on the criteria for mutual assistance. I must acknowledge the Council's determination to defend its demands, without neglecting its willingness to dialogue towards compromise, and the Commission the invaluable mediation work at certain decisive stages of the negotiations, without whose contribution we would not have reached a framework agreement so soon. The text for the vote in this House therefore goes in the direction that Parliament wants. As for the definition of methodologies, which serve to frame crisis scenarios country by country and subsequently to allow interventions in the event of crises, these must be homogeneous, drawn up in accordance with a single model and free from the constraints of non-institutional market players. On the other hand, with regard to the principle of mutual assistance, it is reaffirmed in even more stringent terms, when it is specified that the only element which is recognised in the member states' mutual assistance obligations is only necessary and only if there is no infrastructure, where interconnections therefore allow it. The Member States have a duty to assist each other. There are also more detailed guidelines for the definition of compensation criteria, the nature of which is, however, left to the free will of the respective national authorities. We ran the risk of these negotiations becoming the instrument for changing the balance in the negotiations on the other dossiers of the package, a danger of which we were – I was also aware – well aware but which, I believe, we have overcome, also thanks to the fruitful cooperation with the other fellow rapporteurs. I would like to thank President Busek very much, who has given skilful coordination in the negotiations, my fellow shadow rapporteurs for truly excellent cooperation throughout the stages of this dossier, and Commissioner Cañete, who has worked very well with us.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it’s a real pleasure to be here today to discuss the concluding building blocks of our Clean Energy for all Europeans package. These four legislative acts – the Electricity Regulation, the Electricity Directive, the Risk-Preparedness Regulation and the new rules for the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER) – are the final pieces in the jigsaw. With this, we are completing the biggest legislative package the European Union has ever had on energy policy, and we are finalising a new, modern rulebook for the energy sector across our continent which is fit for the challenges ahead. I thank the European Parliament for its strong support throughout the constructive negotiations. This allowed us to secure a political agreement last December. My special thanks reach out in particular to the rapporteurs: Krišjānis Kariņš, whom I congratulate once more for having become Prime Minister of Latvia in January this year; Flavio Zanonato; and Morten Helveg Petersen. Of course, I would also like to thank Jerzy Buzek, Chair of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, all political group coordinators, and all the shadow rapporteurs involved, without whom these agreements would not have been possible. This close cooperation has made it possible to preserve the complementarity and the consistency of these proposals. We have agreed an ambitious package which will take us one step closer to the completion of the Energy Union. This was one of the priorities of the Juncker Commission that you endorsed almost five years ago. Taken together, the agreed legislation will ensure that the European Union electricity market is more secure, more sustainable and more competitive. In short, these new laws are good for consumers, good for the economy and good for the planet. From a consumer perspective, it is the first time that European energy legislation has included so many measures to protect and to empower consumers. Consumers can become active players and individually benefit and drive the energy transition. This is essential. The cleaner energy transition will not succeed unless we take consumers along and win broad societal support. Through our energy market legislation, consumers will gain better information. Household bills will become clearer so that consumers can better understand what they are paying for. Switching will become easier and faster. In principle, it will become possible within 24 hours as of 2026. Easily-understandable comparison tools will help consumers make rational choices and benefit from lower prices. In this context, I have to mention that the Commission will transmit for the minutes a declaration as regards alternative dispute resolution and on how we will assess the effectiveness of such mechanisms. Smart meters will help consumers save energy through adapted consumption and reaction to market prices. Again, this will help them to save money and benefit directly from more competitive markets. Consumers can become prosumers and can invest in global generation, consume, store or sell electricity to the market. They can do this individually or collectively. For the first time, the new legislation recognises the concept of citizens’ energy communities. With these measures, we will follow up on our pledge to put the consumer at the heart of the Energy Union. The new rules bring advantage also from a wider economic perspective. The rules on the electricity market will make markets more integrated and more flexible. The market will deliver better signals to prompt and enable more investment, in particular in clean and flexible solutions. This in turn will not only have a direct positive impact on the electricity price, it will also create more growth and jobs. We have reinforced regional cooperation and the rules to keep cross-border capacity open for trade. This will bring us a step further towards integrating national markets into a true internal electricity market, which is a precondition for a cost-effective decarbonisation of the power system. The same holds true for the new common framework on capacity mechanisms. This will ensure that such mechanisms will only be used where needed, and if so, that they will be open across borders. This will bring considerable economic efficiency gains. In this context, I have to mention that the Commission will transmit a declaration for the Minutes as regards the ambitious opinion of reform implementation plans, which may be in the context of state aid assessment or separate. Furthermore, the Commission will transmit a declaration as regards the definition of interconnectors, highlighting the difference between electricity and gas. Finally, energy security is vital for our business and economy. With the challenges of the energy transition, we must also ensure security of supply for the economy and for our citizens. The new Risk-Preparedness Regulation will make our system more resilient and will ensure better coordination among Member States and introduce a spirit of solidarity. I come now to my third point: to consider what the new electricity market design brings for the environment and sustainability in a more long-term perspective. We have already agreed ambitious targets for renewable energy and energy efficiency, and the new market design will make a major contribution towards achieving this and will help us to meet our Paris Agreement commitments. The markets will become more flexible, more free for increasing sales of renewable electricity. At the same time, with the new emission limit in future capacity mechanisms we will ensure that the solutions to our security of supply are consistent with our climate objectives. The agreed transition arrangements are realistic, and we will allow all players to adapt to these new requirements. All of the above will help European industry and economy by giving a clear sense of direction, but it will also reduce local air pollution for the benefit of our citizens. We know that our new rules are looked at with great interest also in other parts of the world. I want to underline again that, with this package of measures, we are the first party to the Paris Agreement to have adopted all necessary domestic legislation for fulfilling our commitments. At the same time, it puts us in a good position for the upcoming discussion on the long-term strategy. Thanks to your help, the European Union is showing a clear path for the rest of the world to follow. I look forward to the debate.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy. – Madam President, Commissioner, throughout this parliamentary term the European Union has fallen short of its ambition and its obligation to deepen institutional and political competitiveness and convergence. However, there have been exceptions: the Energy Union and the Digital Union are good examples and that is why we are discussing this legislation here today. It is not enough, however, to move forward. We need to take into account the choices and how they ensure the Union's leadership in the energy transition, industrial competitiveness and people's access to clean, healthy and affordable electricity. We must also ensure the principle of energy efficiency, first of all, to ensure a fair transition, to strengthen transparency and market regulation capacity and to give priority to dispatching production on the basis of renewable sources in order to reduce emissions. A single internal market cannot be synonymous with the market without rules. It has to be a market where you can compete with fair standards in a transparent and coordinated way, without assing safety and innovation.  It is therefore time to shed new light on the European Union and its citizens.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to say that it took us almost three years to adopt this package. This was not the fault of the Commission or of Parliament, but mainly of the Council, which blocked. As a result, we can be satisfied with this package. I was present in the negotiations for ACER. Mr Petersen has conducted the negotiations very well; I would like to confirm this explicitly here. However, we adopted our opinion by a large majority in committee on 21 February 2018. It took us almost all year to reach agreement with the Council! The Commission wanted to give ACER broad rights, and the Council not at all. We have achieved this – and in this respect Parliament has also communicated – that the role of ACER in a changing internal market has been strengthened and changed. Until now, it has been primarily responsible for coordinating, advising and monitoring national regulatory authorities. Today, we have reached the point where ACER has been given limited but decision-making powers, and aCER can have adequate financial resources and supervise the regional coordination centres.  That is why I come to the conclusion: the revision of the ACER regulation has been successful.

name: Martina WERNER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We have worked very hard for two years on the reform of the electricity market. With the result, the new electricity market design, we are today setting the course for a decentralised, sustainable and secure power supply, so that the energy transition can also be achieved at European level.  The choice of energy sources naturally plays a central role in this. Renewables are the energy sources of the future. That is why, as negotiator for my group, I have also worked to ensure that electricity from renewable energy sources is first fed into the grids by means of feed-in priority and, in the event of bottlenecks, also switched off as the last. At the same time, we have ensured that emission-intensive energy sources, such as coal, will no longer be supported by state subsidies in the future. And we Social Democrats have also managed to ensure that citizens' energy cooperatives are given preferential treatment in future and are not subject to disproportionate, unfair and non-transparent rules and costs.  For my group, it was also important to strengthen the protection of consumers for electricity customers. From now on, consumers will be able to compare electricity tariffs from trusted and verified websites and switch providers within 24 hours from 2022. Electricity bills will be easier to understand because the first information will be bundled on the first page.  I would have liked sub-network operators – such as our municipal utilities – to play a more active role in the development of the charging infrastructure for e-mobility. Unfortunately, this has not been won by a majority, and I believe that this is a really wasted opportunity, because it is precisely in the case of electromobility that municipal utilities can push ahead with the nationwide expansion of the charging infrastructure, precisely because they make an enormous contribution to the acceptance of infrastructure projects.  Finally, I would like to take this opportunity to thank my colleagues once again for their very trusting and very cooperative cooperation.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, dear Commissioner, I would like to congratulate all the rapporteurs for reaching another milestone in the completion of the Clean Energy Package, which will provide our citizens with a greener market-based system that better answers the interconnected reality of our European electricity market. As shadow rapporteur for the regulation of risk preparedness in the electricity sector, I strongly welcomed the Commission’s proposal, which is very much needed, as was sadly shown by the uncoordinated cross-border response to the cold spell that affected southern Europe in January 2017. In line with the Emergency and Restoration network code, we worked on structured multilevel frameworks that oblige Member States to define and coordinate their strategies ex-ante. Timely assistance will be enhanced by programming solidarity interventions in a clear and predictable manner, in particular by fixing compensation schemes in advance. I believe the agreement negotiated by our rapporteurs has secured three key elements. It delivers a truly Union approach thanks to a unique risk assessment methodology approved but ACER and the strong involvement of the regional coordination centres in all phases of the planning procedure. It provides for greater transparency and incentives for data sharing, with safeguards for confidentiality, and it minimises collective costs arising from supply disruption and market distortion by allowing non-market-based solutions only as a last resort. The future implementation of this regulation will successfully lower the risk of black-outs and it will also lower the electricity bills for consumers while decreasing our Member States’ dependence on third countries’ energy supply. At the end, I would like to conclude by thanking all the rapporteurs and the negotiating teams for the fruitful and efficient cooperation.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, decarbonising our energy system is an absolute priority, and with these regulations we are taking a step in the right direction. I am pleased that thanks to the Green Group this agreement serves to support renewable energy, demand management and energy cooperatives and that we have put an expiry date on coal subsidies.  It is time for a just transition beyond dirty energies, and that no one has to choose between end of the world or end of the month. But we have to do much more if we are to comply with the Paris Agreement, starting, Commissioner, by not authorising subsidies to new polluting power plants in Poland and Greece. That is why I urge the European Commission to redouble its level of climate ambition. From the Green Group we will be very attentive. We owe this to the Youth for the Climate who leaves their classes every week to give us a master lesson.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Yes, I think we have to ask ourselves, when it comes to electricity market design, whether what has come out is indeed sufficient for the next few decades. Is this determined enough to counteract climate change with something substantial that requires renewable energy? Yes, and the question is also: is this sustainable enough for energy security in the coming years? And is that social enough? Our answer is – if we want to be honest: the glass is half full! We welcome the fact that regulated prices, for example in the electricity market, are maintained, and at the same time we criticise the fact that energy poverty is only half-hearted – with soft wording that we find here.  We are pleased that citizens' energies – and I believe this is a great step forward – are being given regulated rights for the first time, especially when it comes to increasing the acceptance of renewable energies, this is very, very important. But we are annoyed that consumer protection rights do not go far enough. We support the fact that in future the dirtiest coal-fired power stations will be left out of the safety reserve and can no longer be subsidised. But, frankly, it is difficult for us to live with the capacity markets, because we actually need something else, namely a consistent feed-in priority for renewable energies, not just small energy installations, but as a basic rule. Unfortunately, we were not able to achieve this, even though we on the left have been committed to this. So what is half full is also half empty.

name: Jonathan BULLOCK
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, Europe’s electricity crisis is the result of irresponsible energy policy-making choices of the unelected Commission in Brussels. In today’s report, Mr Kariņš addresses fundamental issues such as the intermittency of renewable energy and the collateral effects of the EU energy subsidies. Mr Zanonato, on the other hand, strongly believes that further EU harmonisation shall prevent future electricity crises in Europe. The EU focused its energy policy on unreliable, expensive, intermittent renewable sources. These authoritarian decisions are undermining competitiveness and are driving energy-intensive businesses outside of Europe, increasing what’s called ‘the carbon leakage’ phenomenon. Consequently, we are losing jobs and investments altogether. I sincerely hope that the UK will exit the EU repealing all parts of the EU energy and climate policy, which is failing. The UK has a chance to get back in the real world and invest in reliable energy sources such as nuclear and coal, while also exploring national indigenous energy resources such as the local undiscovered shale gas.

name: Christelle LETARD-LECHEVALIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, which is essential to the operation of our businesses, to the lives of individuals and to travel, energy is, by its very nature, one of the main strategic policies of a State. If, for us, cooperation between Member States on energy is necessary and desirable, national sovereignty in this highly strategic area is not negotiable. Behind the stated objective of combating climate change and protecting consumers, the Commission's ambition is to create a large European electricity market where national logic will have to be erased before its will. The principles of increasing our cross-border trade, managing our peaks or troughs in electricity consumption in cooperation with our neighbouring countries, integrating consumer-generated renewable energy or adapting our production resources to new technologies are, in themselves, positive. However, these are natural steps that Member States have been taking between themselves and in their territories for decades. The Commission's dogmatic aim is to impose by ideology measures that will kill all forms of energy sovereignty and national initiative, both on the technical standardisation for electrical interconnections and on the management of flows between neighbouring countries. The emphasis should be on free cooperation between states, not on a gradual submission to arbitrary and ideological decisions by the Commission and its agencies. Moreover, the Commission is clearly showing its desire for full liberalisation of the energy market. It should be remembered that the non-European examples of excessive liberalisation and privatisation of electricity markets have, for the most part, ended in stinging and costly failures. Each of the four texts of this package is an additional stone to the edifice of the European electricity market and to the dispossession of the Member States of their energy but also diplomatic sovereignty. Here, two visions are at odds: on the one hand, the ultra-liberal vision of the Commission and its accomplices, which brought energy into disrepute as one of many markets to internationalise and open up to competition; on the other hand, our illiberal vision of energy as a public good essential to the functioning of the nation and to be managed on its scale, with free cooperation between states.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, with the debate on the regulation of the electricity market we complete the legislation on the clean energy package. I, Commissioner, would like to congratulate you on the work you have done from the Commission, but I would also like to acknowledge today that this Parliament lives up to the demands and up to the challenge ahead, which is to make energy legislation in line with the Paris agreements and with the great challenge that humanity has , which is the fight against climate change; with greater penetration of renewables; with more energy efficiency; with a more active role of consumers; with a role also—which we do not forget—to combat energy poverty. In short, the European Union is the great global player that has safe legislation and responds to the challenge of this time. We can therefore, as Europeans, be proud of the work we have done and, in turn, claim that more needs to be done, because the challenge is of a huge scale.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: – Dear Chairman, I first take the opportunity, as shadow rapporteur for the ACER Regulation, to thank my colleague Petersen for their excellent cooperation and conducting negotiations that have resulted, of course, that the ambitions we have had as far as ACER is concerned, have not been realised, but nevertheless ACER is sufficient to actually be able to effectively implement the Energy Policy of the European Union throughout the Energy Union package.  What I want to emphasize, I don't think today's colleagues have pointed out, and it concerns actually this electricity market, it is an implementation problem that Commissioner Cañete has repeatedly suggested and spoken to on our committees in exchange of views. Thus, energy poverty is an obligation on Member States that must implement these directives. Citizens' active participation in energy production is also something they have to execute. The integrated climate-energy packages or plans show now that there are risks around how Member States will successfully implement these regulations and directives that we are discussing today. The European Budget, the Cohesion Fund, the European Regional Development Fund, Horizon Europe – we decide on them today and tomorrow how they will actually support with public money precisely the implementation of these directives in the Member States.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Petersen, the shadow rapporteurs and the Austrian Presidency, and, after all, the Commissioner for his very constructive cooperation in reaching a compromise agreement. And I believe that we have managed to reach a very good agreement with ACER that will enable the Agency to function effectively.  We have managed to promote a stronger and more transparent agency, which will, among other things, oversee regional coordination centres. Regional coordination centres will play an important role in situations where TSOs decide on issues requiring a common approach.  I am glad that we have managed to address the agency's long-term lack of financial and human resources. I am glad that all stakeholders have recognised the need to finance more of this agency. I firmly believe that, thanks to the new legislation, ACER will ensure a better functioning of the European single market and will be able to cope with the new challenges that the whole package brings.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to touch on another aspect of this problem and not go back in principle to what we have already agreed on, but to say something about the future and the experience of this process of our work on the legislative proposals that have been included in this package.  Well, It seems to me that the time has come to lay the conditions for a truly just energy transition. Before we implement the next ambitious climate targets – and we know that a completely carbon-neutral EU economy is currently being designed by 2050 – so before we start, let us take care of the people most at risk from the elimination of conventional energy sources such as coal, oil or natural gas. Let us be wary of mass depopulated areas, so-called no-go regions, as in north-west Bulgaria, or even protests by French yellow vests initiated by rising fuel prices. I would not want the scenes from Paris to repeat in other European metropolises.  The energy transition requires an individual approach to individual countries and regions. It requires proper preparation, financial resources. It must go hand in hand with security of energy supply, maintaining the competitiveness of individual economies. Above all, however, at the heart of this process, let us put households, especially those who are already threatened by energy poverty.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, having been involved in the whole climate area all during this mandate, I’m very pleased with the progress it has made. I think that great credit is due to Commissioner Arias Cañete, Mr Ristori and many others, who firstly ensured that the Paris Agreement got over the line and now, too, the Clean Energy Package has put in place all the necessary legislation to deliver it. I think we can be very proud of that. Secondly, connectivity is absolutely vital in this whole area, especially if we want to make greater use of renewables. The sun doesn’t always shine and the wind doesn’t always blow; if it blows in one area, it doesn’t blow in another. So to maximise it, connectivity is absolutely important. The internal market for electricity will help to bring that about. Indeed, there is a group in Ireland with former President of Parliament, Pat Cox, and people like Eddie O’Connor, who recently developed what they call the super node across Europe. That would deliver the connectivity that would be necessary to make maximum use of a renewable source.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the new package on the reform of the electricity market will make it possible to make customers responsible, simplify the cross-border electricity market, guarantee security of supply and facilitate climate-respecting electricity production. Of fundamental importance is the strengthening of consumer rights, establishing clearer information on contract conditions, more transparent energy bills, comparison tools, smart meters to better control consumption and, not least, the possibility of switching suppliers in 24 hours. However, the agreement does not seem to me to be ambitious enough with regard to the transition to clean energy and self-consumption self-handling, which should be strengthened more. The European package should allow the transition from a fossil and centralised model to a decarbonised and decentralised model, with a major step forward for instant self-consumption. The aim, that is, should be to facilitate those who intend to self-production with simultaneous self-consumption within a decarbonised model.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me close by thanking you again for your excellent cooperation and for being such a reliable partner in the course of the negotiations on these dossiers. You have supported and strengthened the level of ambition in the ‘Clean Energy for all Europeans’ proposals, and Europe can be fully satisfied with the results. I trust that in your vote tomorrow you will maintain your ambitious approach and thereby remain such an important player in defining our future energy policy fit for the 21st century. This is an example of a key area where Europe is moving forward. This is an example of promises made to citizens five years ago that are delivered, and this is an example where the role of the European Parliament was decisive in bringing the priorities of our citizens from words to action. For sure, implementation will be decisive, and we will use governmental relations for facilitating the need in the context of national plans for energy and climate. Now that the young Europeans have taken to the streets, asking governments to take action, and now that the European Parliament electoral campaign is going to start, I encourage all of you – European political parties and their Spitzenkanditaten – to explain what you have done and to define and develop in your electoral programmes the vision on these vital issues, seeking the views, the engagement and the support of our citizens.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner. I should now give the floor to Mrs Werner. She has just apologised to me for having to be at a parallel meeting and therefore unable to be present.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President! At the end of 2016, the Commission presented its major energy package. We are now coming to an end this week and looking forward to the next chapter after years of hard work. We will also have a lot of work to do in the next term of office. It can be said that in this we have, of course, focused on adopting legislation which, in the Commissioner's excellent words, is the largest comprehensive energy legislation in the history of the European Union, but these are only papers if it is not implemented. That is why, in the coming years, we will also have an important role in Parliament to ensure that the legislation is actually implemented. This is absolutely crucial to the climate fight, and I think it is fair to say that what we have experienced over the last few years has just been that it is Parliament that has helped to hold on to and even lift its ambitions. I think that is important to say here at the entrance to a European election campaign. We have set higher targets for energy efficiency and for renewable energy, but the renewable energy target depends on the implementation, of ACER, of the electricity market regulation, since cross-border electricity trade is the very prerequisite for green transition.  The next period is also about climate ambitions up to 2050, and to me there is no doubt that the European Union must take the lead. That is why we must aim for the EU to be carbon neutral by 2050. I myself recently experienced at a climate demonstration in Copenhagen that it is clear how the people are demanding action in this area. We must take responsibility for this! Finally, let me conclude by thanking the Commission, the Commissioner once again, and all my colleagues here in the European Parliament for their excellent cooperation. It's a good draw!

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not, to tell the truth, have much to add to what I said earlier, because I agree with what Commissioner Cañete said and I agree with most of the contributions made by my fellow Members who have spoken on the various points. With regard to those few critical speeches that have come from one side of this House, although I have listened to them carefully, I would like to point out that they are not about the current debate, but about the question of whether it is appropriate to create a single energy market, with all the consequences that this entails and with the objectives we have set ourselves. Instead, we are discussing how to do this kind of operation because we are convinced. So the debate is moving on to a subject that is completely different and that is not that of the single energy market. In conclusion, I am pleased to be able to thank once again my chairman, Mr De Clercq, for his excellent report. Buzek. name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Tuesday, 26 March 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – Two and a half years ago, we embarked on a comprehensive reform to make the European electricity market more competitive, affordable and environmentally friendly. As I said from the outset, the most important objective of the current and current reform package can only be to support consumers. We have been sent here by European citizens to represent them, so we must take their interests into account when we create the laws of the future.  The package of proposals proposed by Parlement would have abolished regulated prices for retail customers, relying solely on market fluctuations to establish electricity prices. This step would have eliminated many retail discounts, including the Hungarian overhead reduction, with the stroke of a pen. I am pleased that common sense prevailed during the interinstitutional negotiations and that this prohibition has been removed from the text, and I will therefore vote in favour of the proposal.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Geoffroy Didier's report on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on collective actions for the protection of the collective interests of consumers and the repeal of Directive 2009/22// EC (COM(2018)0184 - C8-0149/2018 - 2018/0089 (COD)) (A8-0447/2018).

name: Geoffroy DIDIER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner Jourov, ladies and gentlemen. Having joined the European Parliament only a year ago, I am measuring the opportunity but also my responsibility to be the rapporteur of such a valuable reform for consumers in all European countries.  Tomorrow, we will make possible collective action against the illegal practices of large companies.  My task was not easy at first. Many feared, for example, that this reform could give rise to abusive, slanderous litigation, which was used to destabilize a competing company and thus reproduce the excesses of the American system. This will not be the case because I have taken special care of it. Others feared that this text would end up in catch-all where it would no longer be only the consumer concerned but the citizen, the individual in all its contours, who would use this remedy to ask a company, for example, to compensate it on the pretext that it would have contributed to the pollution of the air it breathes. This will not be the case because it would have been , as everyone would have acknowledged - distort the spirit of the text which aims above all to protect the rights of consumers. In fact, I think I can say that we have built, in close association with all the shadow rapporteurs, which I would like to thank here warmly for their excellent state of mind, a subtle balance which reconciles, on the one hand, the need for greater consumer protection, on the other hand, the necessary legal security of companies.  This text goes even further since it demonstrates, perhaps for the first time, that both, protection on the one hand, security, on the other, have every interest in going together. Ladies and gentlemen, adopting this text just a few weeks before the European elections could be a great demonstration that when we put ourselves together we make Europe concretely useful to the daily lives of each of our fellow citizens.  Thanks to the European class action, an air passenger, a car buyer, a washing machine owner will be able to take legal action with others against an illegal practice of his airline, his car brand or that of his household appliance.  These consumers will have their rights defended by a qualified entity whose funding will be transparent and will thus be redressed for their harm.  Finally, to establish its legitimacy, our European class action has set itself some fundamental principles. First, this remedy is not a substitute for those already existing in some states. Respectful of national legal traditions, it will be added or create new protection in the nine European countries that did not have it until now. The second principle is that the full compensation will have to go to the consumer. Qualified entities, which will only be vehicles for consumers to enforce their rights, will not be able to benefit from them.  Finally, to avoid abuse, we have established the principle that the loser at trial will pay for the proceedings, but we have also set the rule that one cannot be compensated twice for the same injury. Colleagues, I invite you to vote tomorrow in favour of this reform because it is not the text of any party, ideology or lobby. This directive has only one objective: to better protect the rights of all citizens of Europe.

name: Geoffroy DIDIER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Didier, for his dedicated work on this proposal, as well as all the other Members of the European Parliament from the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO).  The Commission welcomes the swift progress on this file and hopes that Parliament will adopt its first reading position tomorrow. We can all agree that consumers across the EU should be able to enforce their rights effectively in ‘mass harm’ situations, and that is why the Commission proposed this directive. Via the representative actions for the protection of the collective interest of consumers, qualified entities, such as consumer associations or independent public bodies, will be able to act. They will be able to stop infringements of consumer law and help obtain redress for those consumers who have been harmed. This will especially help vulnerable consumers in situations where they shy away from defending their rights individually.  The proposal responds to the need for strong public and private enforcement of EU consumer rights. In line with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, the proposal gives Member States considerable room for manoeuvre on key procedural points. Our aim is to find solutions that safeguard consumer rights and ensure that traders are also treated fairly. From the beginning, we made it very clear that the Commission does not want to create a litigation culture in Europe, and the proposal on representative actions in no way lends itself to such an interpretation. We define a clearly European way of collective redress that is fair for consumers and businesses, that does not contain punitive damages, and is not bringing US—style class actions to the EU. In particular, we set strict standards for qualified entities which want to act on behalf of consumers.  I welcome that the report is pursuing the same objective. In particular, I note the proposed strengthening of the criteria for qualified entities and the preservation of Member States’ discretion as to the precise procedural modalities. Member States share the objective of ensuring clear and effective rules for an efficient and proportionate collective redress system suitable for the European model. I am convinced that, with the new deal for consumers, and in particular with the collective redress initiative, we are sending a clear message to European consumers that the EU cares about them. I therefore think that your vote in this pre-election moment is very important.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I think it is appropriate to start by thanking My colleague Didier for the efforts he has put into negotiating the resulting text, as well as you, Commissioner.  The citizens of the European Union expect a high standard of protection of consumer rights, and this proposal undoubtedly contributes to it. However, the text submitted also rightly contains a number of provisions aimed at preventing the abuse of class actions. I am glad that the resulting text contains a number of insurance policy, such as a ban on parallel disputes, which will prevent class actions from being abused by those who do not care about consumer rights, but only for their own profit. I will therefore vote in favour of the report submitted.

name: Mady DELVAUX
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Madam President, despite fierce lobbying and great resistance from the right of this Parliament, we have reached a good agreement, thanks also to Mr Didier. Today, only 19 Member States have collective action mechanisms and few are really effective. The new draft directive will guarantee european minimum standards that will protect consumers, who will be able to ally themselves to claim compensation against them. For us, the important points were: facilitating the creation of representative entities that can represent consumers, ensuring transparency and the absence of conflicts of interest, speeding up procedures and informing consumers. I am satisfied with the results on these points but I still have two regrets. First, the scope: citizens are not just consumers. Health damage or environmental damage is caused by unscrupulous companies; in that case, would the victims not deserve access to the class action? My second regret is that the Council, wary of this point, has not found a common position. Therefore, an agreement is no longer possible in this mandate and this will delay the implementation of this mechanism, which is an important instrument for consumers.
