name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, a stable internal market requires consumer confidence. Big scandals like dieselgate, but also the privacy violations by Facebook, which violate that trust. They demonstrate the weakness in our European legislation when it comes to the enforcement of consumer law and collective claims. With the legislation we are voting on tomorrow, we are creating a European basis for consumers to act together and recover damages. We are strengthening the position of European consumers. This ensures a better balance between consumer and producer. Tomorrow, as the European Parliament, we will take a step in the right direction. It is now up to the Council to adopt a position quickly and to enter into negotiations with the new Parliament after the elections, so that consumers can now collectively achieve their right throughout Europe.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, the European Union is a Europe of 'business' at the service of banks and lobbies, when it should have been a Europe of peoples. It now holds an opportunity to start catching up by strengthening consumer protection.  The draft directive before us is aimed at creating group action at European level, what the Americans call class action. The aim is to enable consumers, victims of the same prejudice, to come together to collectively defend their interests through joint action before national courts. There is an urgent need to create this procedure because only a few states in Europe, including France, already have it. The result is that American consumers are much better protected than European consumers. In the Dieselgate case, for example, Volkswagen paid 22 billion euros in compensation to its American customers, even though it has yet to pay virtually nothing to its European customers.  The procedure devised by the draft directive will undoubtedly improve the situation because it is wisely designed. It provides that the group action will be presented by non-profit associations. They will inform consumers of the possibility of joining their action and the courts will have to repair the entirety of their harm.  Finally, the draft directive has the merit of respecting the national group actions that already exist, such as those introduced by the French law of 17 March 2014.  It remains to be hoped that this European group action will be more successful than the French group action which has a catastrophic record because of its excessive procedural burden.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! The single market is a good thing! But it is a big area, and often consumers stand as the weaker party in the EU's single market when something goes wrong. That is why we need a legal tool in the European internal market that will strengthen consumers and safeguard their rights. This is the kind of tool we are now in the process of making. I think that's a really good thing! Collective class action - the fact that we can go together to guarantee one's rights with a company - will mean that we can ensure that we have a significantly better internal market. We saw it with the diesel gate scandal. The fact that we do not have the possibility of collective redress at European level has contributed to putting consumers in Europe much worse off than, for example, in the United States. That is why I am very pleased that we are now taking the first step towards securing a real European tool that can empower European consumers. We need that, because that is the way to ensure that we have an even better internal market.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr. Packet, you have appeared with us. Do you want to speak now, on an exceptional basis?

name: Ralph PACKET
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, with the dieselgate, we were faced with the facts. There is something wrong with the application of our European rules and, in the end, the consumer became the biggest victim. Totally abandoned by Europe, by the Member States and by the producers. After all, what consumer wants to fight long, expensive and unclear legal proceedings to compete with these big, powerful companies? That's purely David against Goliath. For me, it is simple: illegal practices should be stopped more easily and consumers should be compensated for the damage they have suffered. In order to fight this battle and to uphold consumer rights, a system of collective action with the necessary safeguards must provide effective force to avoid American malpractice. In Flanders and Belgium we are at the forefront of this field and I hope that our consumers will soon be able to enjoy this important tool all over Europe.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to thank Commissioner Jourova for finally getting something that we as a Parliament have been asking for for a long, long time, but which the Commission has left untouched for a long time, and there is a special thanks for this. I would have liked to have said to the citizens today: man, yes, now we have the association action for you, the European solution, so that you can get your right. Unfortunately, however, the case is this: yes, we are doing a good job, we have good proposals, and this report is a good report and has also been greatly improved by the European Parliament, but unfortunately the Council is not playing along. To date, it has not yet adopted a common position, nor has it adopted a basis for negotiations with Parliament. I find that very regrettable. This puts a great many rights on the back burner for citizens. This prevents us from actually doing what we promised. We want that. We want this right to come at last. And we will continue to work on this in the new parliamentary term too, so that this collective action for the citizens of Europe really comes.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the Honourable Members very much for their interventions. Indeed, dieselgate was one of the impulses which gave us the strength to come with the proposal because we had a very good reason also to explain to the opponents that we need the possibility for European consumers to go and collectively defend their rights. I could name every Member State where there is some case of mass-harm situation. For instance, in Spain, the very difficult situation through the unfavourable contracts with banks for mortgages, it covers 60 000 people and I could continue like this. So this is not only dieselgate, it’s only maybe the most visible case.   I want to thank you for your approach. Again, my thanks to the rapporteur. I believe that your our report will receive the necessary support from the European Parliament. And, as for the support of the Council, we have to do our best to convince the Member States after the elections that this is the necessary step forward to better protect the interests of consumers in the EU and I believe we will get it done.

name: Geoffroy DIDIER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner Jourova has said two very important things. The first is that the objective is not to punish anyone, but to exclusively compensate the victims and to have their harm repaired. The second is that our text has made sure to avoid all the dangers and excesses of American-style class action. Finally, I would like to thank my colleagues, Mr Swoboda, who, in speaking out, showed the full support of my political party, the EPP, Gilles Lebreton, for his constructive state of mind, and Mady Delvaux who, during all the discussions, impressed me with his sense of dialogue and his willingness to seek, and above all to find a compromise. Yes, I would have liked the Council to move faster, but we will ensure, if re-elected, that we continue, and above all, finalise this work within the framework of the trilogue. In any case, count on us, count on me to better protect European consumers, I will not let go.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, March 26, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. – The European Union has the best consumer protection rules in the world, but the current framework does not allow for sound and equitable enforcement of this legislation in the Union. The risk of infringements of EU law affecting the collective interests of consumers is increasing due to economic globalisation and the digitisation of our economy, and the DieselGate case exposed the fragility of European consumers in seeing their rights protected and repaid in large-scale cross-border infringements. More than anything, a basic principle on which the EU is based: access to justice; 500 million European consumers allowing a qualified entity to seek compensation on behalf of a consumer group that has been harmed by an illegal commercial practice. Harmonised common principles are established, but national legal traditions are also respected and bad faith litigation is prevented. Together with the reform we have made in the Regulation on cooperation between national authorities responsible for the implementation of consumer law, with the revision of the Consumer Rights Directive and now with collective actions, we have strengthened and closed the European consumer protection framework with a golden key.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the Commission's statement on recent developments in Dieselgate (2019/2670 (RSP)).

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, three and a half years have passed since Dieselgate broke out. In this time, we learned that European vehicle manufacturers have violated the EU rules on vehicle pollutant emissions. This has been detrimental in many respects. It has affected the air quality and the health of EU citizens, it has affected the trust of EU consumers in EU industry, and it has affected confidence in the whole EU regulatory framework on vehicles.  Together with the European Parliament and the Council, the Commission has spared no efforts to put an end to this scandal, to restore confidence and to avoid any repetition in the future. A lot has already been achieved. In May 2018, we put in place a more efficient regulatory framework that guarantees greater independence and transparency of vehicle type-approval. This will inter alia allow for EU fines, EU—wide recalls and EU testing of vehicles. We have also introduced more accurate testing for NOx emissions with the Real—Driving Emissions (RDE) test procedure. This procedure gives a more realistic picture of actual pollutant emissions on the road, and it also contributes to the effective reduction of these emissions. Let me give a simple example. Thanks to RDE, diesel cars now emit on average 40 mg of NOx per km. Before RDE, these emissions were on average 700 to 800 mg per km in real driving conditions. We now have one of the most effective emission regulatory systems anywhere in the world.  The procedure to measure CO2 emissions more accurately has also been modernised, with the adoption of the Worldwide Harmonised Light Vehicle Test Procedure (WLTP). This allows EU consumers to obtain realistic information on the fuel consumption of vehicles. Both RDE and WLTP are new tests that will be constantly reviewed and adapted where necessary. The Commission has also launched eight infringement procedures against Member States for a violation of the EU type—approval rules since December 2016. Six are still ongoing. They have already resulted in legislative changes and enforcement action in the Member States concerned. In February 2018, the Commission set up a platform in which Member States share the information on recalls of vehicles affected by Dieselgate. Based on this information, the Commission publishes regular updates on the state of play of recalls. So far, the Commission has no legal power to impose mandatory recalls. This still remains the responsibility of the Member States, which are bound to supervise the manufacturers and ensure that recall measures are effectively implemented.  As of 1 September 2020, the new Type-Approval Framework Regulation will allow for EU fines, EU-wide recalls and EU testing. For the time being, there is no comprehensive information on the effects of recalls on air quality. What is certain is that there are still about two million cars on European roads that require updating, and many of these cars are being sold to Central and Eastern Europe. We are moving our air quality problems from West to East. Some of the new rules put in place by the Commission have been challenged before the General Court. This is notably the case of one of the Commission regulations setting up the RDE procedures, and in particular, the so-called conformity factors used in this procedure. These conformity factors are necessary to reflect the statistical uncertainty linked with the new test procedure, as well as the margin of error of the portable measuring equipment. Last December, the General Court ruled that the Commission went beyond its powers when adopting these conformity factors. I want to inform you that the Commission has appealed that judgment. Germany and Hungary also appealed. The Commission is convinced that it did not go beyond its powers. These conformity factors are mere technical requirements that have no bearing on the emissions limits set by the co—legislators. Of course, at the same time I cannot guarantee what will be the outcome of this appeal. This is why the Commission is preparing a proposal, scheduled for adoption in April. The Commission will propose to the co-legislators the adoption of those conformity factors. They should also empower the Commission to lower the second factor as soon as technical progress allows. We have already done that once. So Parliament will now have the opportunity to set the conformity factors together with the Council. This is good news for you. To sum up, as acknowledged by the European Court of Auditors in its recent briefing paper on the EU’s response to the Dieselgate scandal: ‘The emissions scandal has accelerated many legislative changes to the EU system of vehicle emissions checks’. The European Court of Auditors also underlined that more could be done, and that it would take some time before the legislative changes have an impact on air quality.  Because deeds are better than words, together with the help of Member States, the Commission has prepared a ‘Roadmap towards clean vehicles’. It sets out benchmarks and tools for making sure that we will never have to go through a similar story again. The Commission presented the Roadmap on Monday, 18 March 2019, at the Automotive Industry Forum in Craiova. It demonstrates what the Commission is committed to. The Commission will ensure that the commitments made in the Roadmap are fulfilled, and it expects nothing less from the industry and the Member States. Let me also finish on a more positive note. We need to look at the future, and we spare no effort in this respect. We already have ambitious targets for CO2 reduction. We are about to adopt a major initiative to increase road safety and save lives, the General Safety Regulation, and we have to prepare for the revolution of connected and automated vehicles.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Madam President, Commissioner, first of all, I regret that it is not Mrs Bie-kowska who is before us to talk about this famous compliance factor, since it is with her that we have been constantly debating and I am extremely astonished by your speech, very satisfied, about the actions that would have been taken by the Commission since the diesel scandal. First of all, let us go back to this very elastic compliance factor applied by the Commission in the package on real-world testing, which was nevertheless overturned by the Court of Justice, a decision which, unfortunately, was challenged both by some States and also by the Commission. The Court had quashed the act of execution because this compliance factor was contrary to the Euro VI standards on nitrogen dioxide values, the standards that determine vehicle emission thresholds. However, on 20 February, when she appeared before the Committee on Transport and Tourism, in front of the Members of the EMIS Committee, Ms Bie-kowska announced that the Commission would put the same compliance factor back on the table, exceeding the legal benchmark by 110% and then by 50% by 2021. I can't hide my amazement. Giving manufacturers a right to pollute with such a margin of tolerance is an insult to this Parliament and, above all, seriously endangers the air we breathe. If the Commission presents such a proposal, we can only reject it. Manufacturers must take responsibility and recall all vehicles that do not comply with the Euro VI standard.  I note bitterly that the Commission is trying to buy time by launching into a legal battle with the Court of Justice. This time saved for the Commission is wasted time for the planet, but we have not a second to lose and we have no alternative planet. Millions of European citizens take to the streets every week to demand that we, as policy makers, act against pollution with the utmost urgency. The situation is particularly critical for the inhabitants of major European cities who are stifling with these nitrogen dioxide emissions, but it is not just nitrogen dioxide. WHO has established a fine particulate matter threshold not to exceed three days per year. Did you know that in Paris, we are already 19 days apart? 2019 is likely to be the worst year for air pollution, but this is nothing new and there is still no follow-up to the Commission's infringement proceedings against states, either on the part of the States or on the part of the Commission.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, to prevent a second dieselgate scandal, that is what we wanted with a series of recommendations from our committee of inquiry. I myself was vice-chairman of that committee and I continue to follow the case. I have to confess: it's spring, but there's still a lot of work to be done before we can harvest. Commissioner Bieńkowska recently said that dieselgate is not over, and a recent briefing from the European Court of Auditors is not very reassuring either. Newspapers headlined: second dieselgate is possible. Well, I find it difficult to understand that people do not seem to be learning enough from the mistakes. Take the relaxation of the nitrogen standard. In 2016 it was introduced and the introduction of practical tests on the road was rather linked to a weakening of that existing standard. We voted against this relaxation, because all technology is available to respect the nitrogen standard, even in real driving conditions and without a negative impact on CO2 emissions. The European Court of Justice considers that the relaxation of the nitrogen standard is de facto illegal, and what is the Commission doing? She's going to appeal. Good air quality matters to everyone. The technology is available, what is holding the Commission back?

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, there are two points I would like to make tonight. The first is that Parliament never really received a proper response from the Commission to the committee of inquiry. Yes, we did receive a response from Commissioner Bieńkowska, but that was only on the recommendations, not the conclusions. And on some elements she wrote that it was the prerogative of the President of the Commission, so she couldn’t answer. That’s a bit weird if we consider the Commission a college. So this goes beyond air quality. This is also a matter of democratic accountability, and I certainly demand from the Commission before the end of this mandate a full and proper response to our inquiry conclusions and recommendations. The second point I would like to make is that we never cleaned up the mess of Dieselgate. We did come up with new legislation but there are still millions of fraudulent diesel cars being driven around European cities, and what we need is a very strong coordinated European approach. At the moment it is left to the Member States, and what we see happening is that individual Member States take measures in such a way that they might get rid of those cars in their own country, but they will be exported to other European countries. So it remains a European problem, and the effects on millions of European citizens are not being taken seriously. The only institution that can play that role, that can come up with a very strong coordinated European approach, is the Commission. So please, Commissioner, take this seriously and organise a huge summit with all Member States to get these cars off the road and force European car manufacturers to take back these cars and make them comply with European legislation through both software and hardware updates.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I think I will indeed just join the dissatisfaction of the Members here. We of course know that there have been improvements – we’ve been working on them – but there’s still a lot of issues that have not been solved. What my colleague Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy said – that there are still cars running on the streets, heavily polluting, knowing that they are just dieselgate cars, and that the Commission is not even taking action in getting Member States together on that – is really concerning. What I would also like to add to that is a question. We know that there are a couple of infringement cases  (by the way, Commissioner Bieńkowska always promised there will be more infringement cases – that was in the heat of the debate). Was that just to calm Parliament down? Was that just not telling the truth? Or are there still more infringement cases in the pipeline, and where are the others standing? And the last point. We have cases with the Ombudsman. We want more transparency also on the technical working groups. Also here, the Commission is refusing to give the minutes of technical meetings. We really need them, all the more so because otherwise it just feels that the Commission keeps on protecting Member States and covering up their bad positions.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we also have a serious place to look in the mirror from the point of view of consumer protection and the legal protection of citizens. When I have toured different places talking to people, they ask a very factial question about what they can do to combat climate change, reduce emissions, reduce particulate emissions, and diesel vehicle owners in particular ask what their legal protection is when they have acquired these vehicles in good faith and then the truth has been different, especially with regard to emissions during driving. In other hand, it is not just a question of what our legislation looks like, what our actions look like, whether they are sufficient, but also of consumer confidence in the products that are manufactured and which we accept through the legislation. I would therefore see that we need to think more broadly about the whole of internal combustion engine technology, the future of diesel vehicles as a whole, and how they can be replaced and how to ensure that biodiesel made from waste and residues also enters the market when there seem to be difficulties. So we have a lot of big questions that need answers – not just that after dieselgate, the work seems to be halfway there. We genuinely have a great deal of things to fix that need to be put in order, both in our legislation and in confidence in the citizens.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, two years after our committee of inquiry, which sought to shed light on the dieselgate scandal, it is the words that best describe the follow-up by the European Commission, the Member States and the car manufacturers to the emissions scandal. It is true that we now have new rules on the type-approval of vehicles, based on tighter market surveillance, and we are working on Collective European Compensation, which I hope will protect citizens from any future scandal caused by the unlawful use of emission manipulation strategies. But the truth is that dieselgate weighs like a boulder, because its legacy is still to be faced. As long as the 43 million dirty diesel vehicles remain in circulation due to the lack of mandatory recalls throughout Europe, until manufacturers have paid for defrauding citizens and for hanging the air we breathe in our cities, we will not be able to write the word end to the emissions scandal. That is why today we are demanding that the Commission and the European governments fully assume their responsibilities before the citizens who, like us, are waiting for that comprehensive response, which has never arrived, to the work carried out by the EMIS Committee of Inquiry. Millions of people are asking us to withdraw the most polluting vehicles and they are wondering whether Europe will have the courage to ask manufacturers to bear, for example, the costs of retrofitting programmes.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Madam President! I feel a little the same as my colleagues in this Chamber have also said: I simply cannot understand why the Commission can praise itself for the work that has been done. I am surprised that you can be so happy with it. Yes, we have new rules and yes, it is good that we got them and that they will apply from 2020. But the big problem is that millions of polluting diesel cars are still running on European roads. Many of our Member States have not even ensured that cars which do not comply with the rules are recalled and repaired! Surely it cannot be right that we cannot make it work. I believe that it is about twenty of our Member States that do not comply with these rules. It's a huge problem!  The problem with these diesel cars is that they pollute - they damage the environment and they damage people's health. We know this and we know which cars are involved. I cannot therefore believe that the Commission can be satisfied with what has happened when so many of these cars are still driving around. Something must be possible to ensure that the Member States do something - and in the future we also need to ensure that something is done! It must then be compulsory to recall cars if problems arise. In addition, we must also ensure that, after being adjusted and corrected, they are tested independently so that we can be sure that they are complying with the rules.  As has also been said, we need to have much more transparency on this at technical level. It must be possible for NGOs and others to help check whether the rules we have are being complied with. It is therefore extremely important that we ensure that the existing fleet of cars in Europe is also cleaner. It is important for public health and it is important for our environment and for our climate. In addition, we must also prevent these polluting cars from being sold on to Eastern Europe, where they may not have as much money and may therefore be tempted to buy them. Surely it is not right that they should then have to live with these environmental consequences. We need the Commission to act now. It can't go fast enough!

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Dieselgate scandal was an obvious scandal. Unfortunately, the car companies did not take all the costs. It is the customers who have often been left alone and are trying to pursue claims for defective cars that have been sold to them through class actions. However, the fight against rogue manufacturers must not mean fighting diesel car owners at all. For many years, drivers have been told that modern diesels are eco-friendly and durable. They bought these cars, and today, through bans on entry to cities, they are put against the wall. That's not the way to go. The fight for clean air in cities must not come at the expense of their residents or commuters, and the costs of these bans must not fall on the least well-off. Common sense must also be exercised for the sake of the environment.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, almost four years since the Dieselgate scandal broke. In total, more than 30 million diesel vehicles were polluting beyond the permitted limit. This very Parliament has set up a commission of inquiry, made recommendations, all of which have gone unanswered. And now we suffer air pollution without reacting, we leave trash cars on our roads, we leave consumers cheated without repair. And the Commission, rather than responding to these emergencies, prefers to say to the manufacturer: you do not know how to meet the standards, it does not matter, continue to pollute. But we're dreaming! What we are asking for is to learn from Dieselgate and implement our recommendations. We have chosen the health of citizens against the interests of the builders. Who do you drive for? So, stop talking, now there's room for action!

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for tonight’s debate.  I found all your questions and comments to be very pertinent.  Many of you have referred to the infringement procedures concerning the follow-up to Dieselgate. In 2016, the Commission opened 18 infringement procedures against Germany, Spain, Luxembourg, Lithuania, Greece, the UK, the Czech Republic and Italy, which had either failed to impose fines on car manufacturers for breaking European Union rules or did not fully implement international legislative sanctions on car manufacturers breaking European Union emission rules. In 2017 and 2018, the Commission sent complementary letters of formal notice to Germany, Luxembourg, Spain and the UK to request further information. A letter of formal notice was also sent to Italy regarding the emission control strategy used by Fiat 500x Euro 6 diesel model. The information received from the Member States so far is neither fully satisfactory nor complete, and in addition, new cases of emission irregularities are being reported. The Commission will continue to follow up these cases.  Some of you also have referred to the recalls. Our Recall Information Platform was launched on 6 February 2018, and almost all Member States are regularly updating the information on mandatory and voluntary recalls and the results of this platform are public. Today, only eight Member States have issued a mandatory recall for vehicles of the VW group with illegal defeat devices. Those are Austria, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Netherlands, Portugal and Slovenia. In the European Union, the wide recall rate of the affected VW models, equipped with the EA189 engine, is at 80% as of 18 March 2019. Unfortunately, in some Member States, there are still recall rates below 50%. Our overall objective is to reach a 100% recall rate and as our first step, as announced in Craiova (Romania) in the Roadmap towards clean vehicles, a minimum European Union-wide recall rate of 90% should be reached by the end of 2019. You can be sure that the Commission is committed to making sure that we get to the bottom of Dieselgate. The Member States and industry must take all measures still necessary in order to be able to close the Dieselgate chapter. We will continue working on the implementing rules for the type-approval framework. We will make sure that the emission rules continue to be fit for purpose. We will also be vigilant regarding the implementation of the new rules and offer all the support the Member States need to put new market surveillance rules in place.  But it has to be stressed that implementation and enforcement is primarily the responsibility of the Member States themselves, as is the recalling of non-compliant cars from circulation and fixing them. So yes, there is still work to be done and we expect all the parties – Member States and industry – to work together in order to be able to turn the page. We count on the continued support and engagement of the European Parliament to achieve this goal.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, March 28, 2019. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - 'Almost two years after the end of the work of the European Parliament's Committee of Inquiry into the Dieselgate Scandal (EMIS), not enough has been done to remove millions of diesel cars from the road that pollute more than manufacturers and type-approval authorities have said'. This is clearly stated by the Court of Auditors, in its reflection paper of last February entitled 'The EU's response to the Dieselgate scandal'. Following the Commission's decision to initiate infringement proceedings against Germany, Luxembourg, the United Kingdom and Italy, there has been no progress in the procedure beyond the first stage, since the Member States have decided not to cooperate sincerely with the Commission and it is hard to understand why, despite the large number of highly polluting vehicles in circulation, the Commission has not been able to cooperate fully with the Commission. , member states' recall campaigns concern only a limited number of vehicles manufactured by the following brands: Volkswagen, Renault, Daimler, Opel and Suzuki. The eyes of the world are on the European Union, as a world leader in the fight against climate change. Our credibility depends on the answers we are able to give.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – In the United States, dieselgate scammers have returned millions of vehicles and collected compensation. In Europe, the origin of fraud, the brands involved have not withdrawn a car or paid a euro, thanks to the protective shield of the institutions. It was shameful to see how before court rulings banning the movement of diesel, the Commissioner for Transport, spurred by the sector to come to her aid criticizing these rulings, or as the Commissioner of Commerce sent a simple tug of ears to the sector by means of a letter. In payment under this excessive protection, builders set up factories in China or India, and recent statements by managers warn of thousands of layoffs because of the electric car. Luckily, the electrification of transport is unstoppable. Unfortunately for the European sector, almost all electric cars sold worldwide are manufactured outside the EU. If efforts and resources to deceive and pollute had focused on technologies of the future, European builders would not have stolen their cheese. Meanwhile, vehicles that emit up to 12 times more GHGs will drive for years or decades than their labelling without authorities protecting our health and environment doing anything.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: – Madam President, I have a point of order. The Commission did not answer my question on why it did not respond to all the recommendations and conclusions of the inquiry committee. I’m not asking the Commissioner to respond to that immediately, but maybe you can, as President, ask the Commission to come back to that in writing as soon as possible, preferably still this week so that we can take action.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Thank you for that advice, Mr. Gerbrandy. That is indeed what we are going to ask the Commission.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report by Michael Boni, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, research and energy, on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on tyre labelling in relation to fuel efficiency and other key parameters and repealing Regulation (EC) 1222/2009 (COM(2018)0296 - C8-0190/2018 - 2018/0148 (COD)) (A8-0086/2019).

name: Michał BONI
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner. I wanted to thank all the co-rapporteurs very warmly. General compromises have been reached despite the initially significant disagreement. Tomorrow's vote will determine a few things. It is important to look for sensible, viable solutions to implement, and unfortunately not everything today is possible, because there are no real technical tests. We therefore oblige the Commission to undertake some of its tasks before the next revision of the directive. But what is important for today? The transport sector accounts for one third of the Union's energy consumption and road transport accounts for 22% of total greenhouse gas emissions. Tyres, mainly due to rolling resistance, account for 5-10% of the vehicle's fuel consumption. The new tyre labelling model will provide consumers with greener, safer and quieter vehicles and reduce the decarbonisation of the transport sector. This is a significant step forward. It requires full information to users about fuel consumption, wet grip, external tyre rolling noise. The updated label will inform you about grip on snow and ice, which until now has not been. For the first time, truck and bus tyres, C3 tyres are included in the labelling and requirements, which in the future will allow retreaded tyres to be subject to the rules when a new method of testing their performance is required. This will increase efficiency and bring tyres into the circular economy. We have required an obligation to review the Directive in order to speed up work and force tests to assess the effect of tyre abrasion in the course and the secretion of microplastics. This is important for the protection not only of the environment, but also of the health of each of us. The requirements for label exposure are new, including for distance selling and online sales.  These new requirements will dramatically improve the visibility of all information to consumers. The Regulation also improves transparency and enforcement, as it introduces an obligation to register tyres in the product database. The same information should also appear on the tyre sales invoice provided to the customer or be attached to the invoice. Therefore, you will be able to better understand the products and compare them according to the relevant criteria. As a result, we have a transparent solution for consumers, accelerating the environmental quality of tyres and their functioning, healthier and safer.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the existing tyre labelling regulation dates from 2009 and requires the Commission to review it in view of technological progress. After a two—year review, the Commission adopted a proposal to revise the existing rules for tyre labelling as part of the third mobility package in May last year. It is an important proposal because road transport is responsible for 27% of final energy consumption in the European Union and 20% of the European Union’s total greenhouse gas emissions.  Moreover, rolling resistance of tyres accounts for 5% to 10% of a vehicle’s fuel consumption. Therefore, having an up-to-date tyre label provides consumers with the necessary information to allow them to review their fuel consumption and save money. In fact, we estimate that an updated labelling scheme could save annually as much as 129 petajoules (PJ) of fuel by 2030, or savings of 10 million tonnes of carbon dioxide per year – the equivalent of removing almost 4 million passenger cars from European Union roads. For consumers, this would result in EUR 7 billion annual savings in fuel costs.  Let me start by congratulating the rapporteur and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) on the progress made in Parliament. I believe that his report strengthens the Commission proposal on several points, and in particular on the rule for showing the tyre label on the internet, on the visibility of the tyre label vis-à-vis consumers in shops and with the links with international regulations on tyres.  I am also pleased that the report supports the Commission proposal as regards the inclusion of tyres in the product registration database established for energy labelling.  However, the Commission considers that it could be further strengthened in the following areas. Firstly, the report’s text leaves the performance levels and related label classes from the 2009 Regulation almost unchanged. However, in the meantime, tyres in the bottom classes (F and G) can no longer be sold on the Union market, as they are banned by the General Safety Regulation. Although the proposal removes the G class and greys out the F class, leaving the remaining classes as they are today means that there is no additional incentive for tyre manufacturers to innovate and bring more efficient and safe products to the market. Secondly, abrasion of tyres is the major source of microplastics in the environment. Addressing this is a key priority for the Commission under the recently adopted Plastics Strategy. Therefore, the Commission considers that as soon as a reliable testing method is available, new rules should be set as quickly as possible. Delegated acts would be a much quicker way of doing this than a full legislative proposal as envisaged now by the report. Finally, there are several other points of concern, such as the weakening of controls by Member States, removing the obligation to show the label in visual advertisements and making the inclusion of the ice and snow logo voluntary instead of mandatory.  I am confident that these issues can be addressed in the next phases of the co-decision process.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- Madam President, I also wanted to thank the rapporteur, Mr Boni, for his sense of listening and openness. However, from my point of view, the account is not there. We have become too accustomed, here and in the Commission, to talk about consumers, consumers, always consumers and rarely citizens. I also want to talk about the citizens, and in particular the responsible citizens. So, of course, this report on labelling may not save the world's face, but it is a first step towards transparency, and that is all the better. But it's important not to miss the mark. You have mentioned this, Commissioner: micro-plastics account for around 300,000 tonnes each year at the European Union level, which are dumped on the roads and playgrounds where our children play. To that, the report does not respond. Through our amendments, we call for real tests on abrasion, to enlighten and protect citizens, and for the manufacture of less polluting and more energy-efficient tyres. Finally, because we cannot ignore what comes from outside, we ask for the traceability of the rubber used and we demand that it come from sustainable forests, without pesticides that pollute the groundwater, for example.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Dear Chairman, Mr Commissioner, colleagues and colleagues, as road transport consumes around 25% of one quarter of total energy consumption and tyres account for around 10% of this consumption, we are actually talking about several percentages of total energy consumption and it is important to work on this.  However, tyres have no impact only on fuel consumption, have an impact on safety, health protection and noise levels, and therefore it is logical that after 10 years we are renewing this Regulation with new consumer information rules and, of course, motives and incentives to buy better tyres so that, in fact, investment in more expensive tyres is actually obtained by saving on lower fuel consumption.  Equally, I welcome the ban on the use of tyres of the lowest quality, and we remain, of course, open to the introduction of abrasiveness, as well as tyre mileage when data on these parameters are available and credible.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, regulation on tyre labelling is an area where rigour and transparency are essential, given that it is a high-consumption product that stifers risk safety, life from death, sustainable production of deregulated exploitation of resources, environmental quality from worsening pollution and the accumulation of waste. The principle of transparency and communication, as the Commissioner knows, based on the robust recording of the necessary data, must allow this legislation we are examining to be useful for the sector and, at the same time, foster a circular approach to resource management. The work of the rapporteurs - which I welcome - will allow us to adopt useful regulations that improve energy regulation, sustainability and safety, while defending consumers, without jeopardising the competitiveness of European industry. A regulation that, in short, will help us to put the European Union on safer wheels.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for your contributions to this debate. Reducing the climate change impact of the transport sector is a key objective of our energy and mobility policies. Given the contribution of tyres’ role and assistance in the fuel consumption of cars, buses and trucks, it is important to ensure that users are provided with up-to-date and accurate information about tyre performance. The aim of the Commission proposal is therefore to strengthen the information requirements on fuel efficiency, noise and safety aspects of tyres and make labels more visible and reliable. I encourage the European Parliament to fully support the ambition of the Commission proposal to ensure that tyre users can make the best choice from an energy efficiency and safety perspective, and can gain financially. I look forward to our further discussions on this important proposal in the next phases of the co—decision process.

name: Michał BONI
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Thank you very much, including the participants in this short discussion, for all these comments that have been well communicated. I think that the document we have prepared is a good basis for future trilogues, probably already in the new parliament, and it will certainly be necessary to pay attention – in addition to what we have already achieved, I am thinking here about good information on labels – also to what Mr Martin pointed out, namely to speed up the work that will involve (...).  (The President interrupted the speaker due to lack of translation) I will continue in English. Thank you very much again to all: to the Commissioner, to all our cooperators. I think that it is a very good background for future work in trilogues, probably in the future Parliament, and I think that we understand how important it is to have clear information addressed to consumers. But I fully agree with Mr Martin that we need to discuss and speed up our work so as to avoid the negative consequences of tyres. We are talking about microplastics, and it should be part of our European fight against the negative consequences of using plastic.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, we are celebrating 40 years of Labour Party representation in the European Parliament. Labour women have played a huge role in the life of this Parliament: not just on the Women’s Rights Committee, but leading in other areas such as economy, internal market, international trade, health and environment, foreign affairs, development, culture and education. I want to pay tribute to the pioneering women who came before me, and the sisters who stood alongside me in 2014: Janey Buchan, Barbara Castle, Ann Clwyd, Joyce Quinn, Christine Crawley, Carole Tongue, Pauline Green, Anita Pollack, Angela Billingham, Veronica Hardstaff, Glenys Kinnock, Eluned Morgan, Susan Waddington, Arlene McCarthy, Linda McAvan, Nina Gill, Catherine Stihler, Mary Honeyball, Glenis Willmott, Lucy Anderson, Anneliese Dodds, Theresa Griffin, Judith Kirton-Darling, Clare Moody and Alex Mayer. It is 100 years since women won the vote; now we have a statue of Millicent Fawcett in Parliament Square, commemorating the Suffragette movement. She’s holding a sign that reads: ‘courage calls to courage everywhere’. Well, we need that courage more than ever now, so I call on women across the UK and Europe to step up the fight to defend European values.

name: Miroslavs MITROFANOVS
text: – Madam President, I will speak about the imbalance in migration processes within the EU. The European Union ensures freedom of movement for the labour force, but the structure and direction of this movement at the present moment are unfavourable for the majority of new Member States because the poorest EU countries are losing well—educated people, who are leaving for developed EU countries. This process promotes the degradation of the social structure and undermines economic cohesion. In the next legislative period, we must elaborate a system of direct EU financial support for several categories of highly skilled professionals in new Member States in order to motivate them to continue working at home. A compensatory mechanism may be applied up to the moment when the difference in salaries between the so—called ‘old’ and ‘new’ Member States becomes less pronounced and stops pushing people to leave their homes. I am speaking above all about doctors and other medical personnel. Let’s come back to this idea after the elections.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I am very concerned about the state of diplomatic relations, since the world and diplomacy in its classical sense is dying. Increasingly, refusal to negotiate and maintain contact with those with whom one has disagreements is being practised – it’s presented as a brilliant diplomatic move. Even during the Cold War there were many diplomatic channels through which it was possible to clarify the situation, find acceptable solutions and, most importantly, avoid an armed conflict that could flare up even by misunderstanding. Now, some have begun to put an ‘equals’ sign between the act of negotiating and agreeing with the position of the other side.  In diplomacy, conducting a dialogue does not mean that you agree with the position of the partners in the negotiations. It is a way to hear and to be heard. Diplomacy is not about being proud and sitting in a corner and accepting a huge amount of aggressive and useless reports. It’s necessary to return to diplomacy as an instrument for resolving problems in relations between countries.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, this just might be the last Monday night that I get an opportunity to stand here and represent the people of the north of Ireland who voted to remain within the EU, because Brexit is dragging us out of the EU against the democratically expressed wishes of the people who voted to remain. Brexit is dismantling the Good Friday Agreement. It’s knocking down its pillars bit by bit and the British Government is no longer even pretending to act with rigorous impartiality or political neutrality. It is appeasing unionism by scrapping 50-50 recruitment in policing and scrapping the Good Friday Agreement guarantees for rights and equality. Nationalism and republicanism have turned their backs on Westminster, rejecting all of the candidates who were willing to take their seats in that parliament, and this is because the majority of the people in the north of Ireland who voted to remain within the EU are seeing what the British Government is doing as a consequence of Brexit and the majority of the people in the nationalist republican community are rejecting the fact that the British Government is dragging us out of here against our wishes. So, once again, as I stand here, I say to you, to all the people who are listening in on the screens, that even though this is the last opportunity that I might get here on a Monday night to represent them, perhaps if the solution to Brexit, which is Irish unity, is something that is embraced by all then there may be an Irish republican back here representing the people of the north of Ireland in the future.
